sources.full: Grim Press Karthax the Living Tower

adventure.name: Grim Press Karthax the Living Tower

entries.name: Background
entries: The orc race, with their imposing physical and fearsome presence often strike fear into the hearts of the more populous and common mortal races. Yet this race is often misunderstood — while they value physical prowess and strength of arms above all else, they also have a strict code of honor that most members of their species rigidly adhere to. A proud species, orcs are prone to be easily offended by those not familiar with their ways, a factor which perhaps leads to other races' perceptions of them.

Orcish society is patriarchal, with strong, prominent chieftains often siring equally strong offspring that in turn are groomed from a young age to lead a clan with honor and dignity. Orcish society is loosely divided into three castes. The warrior caste has a prominent role within orcish societies and will often lead sorties against the settlements of other species, for conquest earns both gold and resources as well as renown and respect within orcish society. The crafter  caste, the most numerous in orcish society, consists of those orcs who both till the earth for food as well as builders responsible for the construction of orcish settlements and forging of weapons and armor. The final caste, ritualists, is charged with preserving the ancestral knowledge of their species, and pass the lore of their people down through generations. This caste is revered, for they summon forth ancestral spirits thought to bring gentle rains that nourish crops, ensure hunters arrows are true, and bless particularly strong warrior bloodlines with fertility.

While orcs generally choose to live in peace far from other races, the discovery of precious metals and gems (specifically sanguarite) within the wastelands has led to an encroachment on orcish territory by other races pursuing the newly discovered wealth within. Warriors and scouts were dispatched to observe the intruders and take note of their strength. However, several prominent members of the ritualist caste argued forcefully that these invaders must be driven back from orcish territory.

Dhugar Bloodsinger, the most prominent among these ritualists, led a powerful raiding party against a group of steadholders that began construction of a new frontier settlement upon orcish grounds. This raiding party included a number of orcish warriors and other ritualists who laid waste to the settlement.

Druvok Steelhead, brother of Dhugar Bloodsinger, led a smaller group in an effort to intercept his brother and prevent an escalation in hostilities with the other nearby races. Their pursuit was too late. Druvok thus set out in pursuit of his brother, who was also pursued by the remnants of the steadholders into the wastelands in which The Living Tower is hidden.

Dhugar and his remaining forces entered The Living Tower, bartering with Karthax for escape from the furious surviving steadholders. These steadholders, pursuing revenge, were offered as much and entered shortly thereafter. Druvok and his hunters, seeking to restore honor to their clan by bringing Dhugar to justice, entered perhaps a few hours later.

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: As with so many adventurers, the pursuit of an orcish raiding party has led a band of adventurers to The Living Tower, where they were offered and accepted entrance. This particular floor is a simple exploration, and while there are hints to the magical nature of The Living Tower — notably an inability to escape to the main floor as well as a desecrated ancient shrine used by Dhugar Bloodsinger to initiate a forbidden blood ritual using the sacred sanguarite to summon an ancestral blood spirit to destroy their enemies that was once a part of an ancient temple devoted to the worship of the Eld Gods.

As with much of The Living Tower, not everything is as it seems. While there are common stereotypes regarding the orcish race throughout many genres, in the world we envision, orcs are often misunderstood due to their appearance and cultural value on physical strength. In fact, in most cities outside the relatively wild frontier region, they are highly regarded for their strength and strong sense of honor, and are welcomed as opposed to regarded with suspicion.

Sanguarite is regarded as sacred to the ritualists, and in particular, Dhugar Bloodsinger, who has been seeking to use the sacred stones to summon ancient blood ancestors to the aid of the orcish clans.
Consider the following when having the adventuring party explore the first floor of The Living Tower:

items: The first floor was once a place where the meager followers of Karthax who survived extermination at the hands of their enemies found refuge. It has long since been abandoned, however, as evidenced by the dilapidated state of this floor.

While Druvok will initially regard the adventurers with a healthy dose of suspicion, if they prove to be beings of honor, Druvok and his party will likely choose to ally with them in an effort to bring his brother to justice and restore honor to his clan.

A number of clues and hints to the ancient nature of The Living Tower may be found within this floor: the magical barriers preventing escape, the ancient shrine devoted to Karthax used by his long-deceased followers, and the omniscient but subtle presence of Karthax constantly observing the adventurers.
This floor is also inhabited by Paewyn Tealeaf, an intrepid explorer and treasure hunter, who has a fondness for orcs thanks to having one as an adopted younger brother.

An aldravex - a tiny, squirrel-like treasure hunting creature able to detect precious metals and gems is also exploring this floor in a search for treasure. It may lead the adventurers to a hidden treasure room or to the {@b Sanguarite Amulet} held by Dhugar Bloodsinger.

entries: Dhugar is a recent guest - such an interesting story he brought to my doorstep!  〄

entries.name: Dhugar Bloodsinger
entries: An orc of the ritualist caste, Dhugar Bloodsinger was identified at birth by one of the oldest and most revered orcish shamans as one who was particularly attuned to the spirit world. Despite the fact Dhugar's father was a mighty warrior respected within the clan, the young orc had a hunched posture and was relatively weak physically, in stark contrast to his formidable older brother, Druvok. Yet despite his sickly frame and malformed spine, Dhugar was revered by those within his tribe thanks to the premonitions of the shaman at his birth. Such reverence led to the young orc developing an arrogant attitude as well as a superiority complex. Despite the elder ritualists' attempts to temper the young orc's attitude with teachings of humility and service toward his clan, as well as the occasional harsh lesson delivered by a stout oak stave, Dhugar nonetheless maintained a belief that he was destined for greatness.

Dhugar's attitude often led to conflict with other orcs his age, in particular Druvok. Where Dhugar was small in stature, clever, manipulative, and could begin ritualistic incantations even at a young age, Druvok was powerful, formidable in stature, and regarded by the clan as a soon-to-be mighty warrior capable of bringing much honor to his family. This led to Dhugar resenting his brother, where he perhaps would have been better served humbly pursuing the ritualist path ordained for him at birth.
Despite his resentment, Dhugar grew in knowledge and power, and soon became a widely respected shaman while his brother was leading raiding parties against other clans, as well as other races.

Ever jealous, however, Dhugar sought to sway the favor of members of the crafter caste toward himself. Thus the ritualist began increasing his influence and amassing a band of followers, counter to the teachings of the elder shamans who taught him the ways of the spirit world.

When other races began to settle near the lands of his clan, the arrogant and power-hungry shaman grew increasingly agitated and frustrated with a perceived lack of action advocated by Druvok and members of the warrior caste. Druvok, having battled numerous times against the members of other species, knew well their threat, and that the rapidly increasing numbers of expeditionary forces toward the nearby wastelands might lead to conflict that would likely lead to the extermination of their clan. The steadholders, settlers, and miners had not yet become aware of the orc clan. Druvok did not yet know their true strength and the settler's true motivations — important factors before choosing to engage in open war.
Despite his older brother's hesitations, Dhugar and his followers chose to attack first and drive away the trespassers before they became too powerful to overcome.

The raid itself was rather successful, but the ritualist's lack of battle experience resulted in many wounded followers. Nonetheless, they were able to eliminate most of the steadholders, liberating a prestine Sanguarite Amulet (a stone said to allow a ritualist to commune with orcish ancestral spirits) in the process.

Dhugar Bloodsinger and his followers retreated into the wastelands, erroneously believing the vengeful steadholders would not pursue them. They traveled at pace, and at times some orcs would lose their way, ensnared by the illusions and enchantments concealing The Living Tower in their wounded state.

After several days of being pursued, Dhugar's depleted band of followers pierced the illusory shroud surrounding The Living Tower, and in exchange for escape from their steadholder pursuers, were offered entrance into The Living Tower.

{@b Roleplaying Dhugar Bloodsinger.} Dhugar Bloodsinger is an orc of small stature, hunched over and cloaked in a humble ritualist's cloak. A shrewd and calculating orc, Dhugar is cunning and perceptive, as well. Having been taught by other shamans of his clan from a young age, Dhugar is capable of summoning fourth ancestral spirits, as well as wielding blood magic that is typically used by ritualists to bless both land and clan with fertility. Dhugar can be portrayed as follows:

items: When interacting with his remaining followers:  "{@i Soon my brethren, we shall be blessed by our ancestors with the ability to eliminate these trespassers!}"
If interacting with Druvok (spitting in disdain):  "{@i My brother, the cowardly warrior. I have acted where you shy away from duty to protect your people!}"
When confronted by the adventuring party:  "{@i Pah, more outsiders. I shall eliminate you as well. Behold the ancestral power of the orcs!}"

entries.name: Druvok Steelhead
entries: The elder brother of Dhugar Bloodsinger, Druvok Steelhead has been trained in the ways of the warrior by the armsmasters of their clan from a young age. In his youth, he participated in countless battles of strength with other younglings — few of whom could match his strength or speed with an axe.

Seeing much potential in the young warrior, Druvok was chosen by his tribe to lead his first war party against a rival clan at a particularly young age. It was during this raid that the orc earned his second name, steelhead — for an opponent very nearly took his head, instead shearing a portion of his scalp away. Once the raid was complete, a crafter molded a piece of steel to fit in place of his scalp, which was in turn healed by a ritualist and infused into his skull as a badge of honor for his first raid.
Despite his fearsome appearance, Druvok adheres to a strict warrior code — to take a life only when needed, and to seek honor and renown in both battle and service to his clan.

The scheming and machinations of his younger brother, Dhugar Bloodsinger, often caused Druvok to regard him with suspicion, for the warrior could not predict the actions of one who does not adhere to a code of honor.

It thus came as no surprise to Druvok when Dhugar led a band of overzealous followers to destroy a band of steadholders; the rash ritualist failing to observe his enemy before striking. Learning of this raid, Druvok led a small warband to attempt to intercept the ritualist, but not arriving in time to prevent an unnecessary slaughter counter to the warrior's code.

Seeing that his younger brother was being pursued by a vengeful mob of steadholders, Druvok and his band of hunters set forth in pursuit, taking care to conceal their presence from additional pursuit, before coming to the entrance to The Living Tower. There, Karthax offered the orcish warrior the opportunity to pursue his brother, bring him to justice, and restore honor to his tribe.
{@b Roleplaying Druvok Steelhead.} A powerful orcish warrior, Druvok Steelhead is calculating and thoughtful, yet decisive once a course of action has been decided upon.

The orc speaks in low, guttural tones, but with an underlying thoughtfulness that indicates he is able to work through the mindset of others. Unlike many other orc warriors who draw steel first and ask questions later, Druvok will engage others before blood is spilled unnecessarily.
Druvok can be portrayed as follows:

items: When interacting with the adventurers, in low, calm tones with a hint of threat:  "{@i I would have no quarrel with you. All I seek is justice for those whose blood has been unnecessarily spilled.}"

When interacting with Dhugar:  "{@i Brother, I knew you schemed and planned, but never did I think you would be so reckless and dishonorable. Come with me and seek atonement in the eyes of our ancestors.}"

entries.name: Paewyn Tealeaf
entries: As a young child, Paewyn Tealeaf grew up in a large desert city that was a major trade center. Merchants hawking their wares, trade caravans passed through daily bearing all manner of goods, and wealthy nobles sought exotic rarities to add to their collection. She was part of a family consisting of her adopted father, a very clever halfling merchant, an elven mother of noble heart who often took in the urchins and poor children of the city, and a young orcish brother who was also taken in by their adopted parents. While initially wary of her larger sibling from a young age, the two quickly embraced each other with their tendency toward finding all manner of trouble as they grew.

Paewyn was nimble of both mind and hand and she learned from her paternal uncle the skills one could not learn in a school — to pick locks and pockets as well as to conceal (and use) daggers with which to protect herself. She quickly developed quite the reputation and few would cross her after a glance at her hulking brother.

While initially her exploits centered around relieving the wealthy of their gold and jewels (they would hardly miss them, she would rationalize), Paewyn grew bored of such simple thievery. Thus she and her brother would begin to venture into the desert, seeking ancient ruins and mausoleums to explore, seeking treasures with which to expand her father's business — which she had since taken over as "Tealeaf Treasures", an enterprise selling adventuring equipment as well as the occasional item liberated from the tombs of the dead.

Her exploits grew more and more bold, her business dealings becoming more shadowy, and her thirst for exploration became insatiable. Paewyn had heard rumors of ancient ruins and treasures to the north, uncovered by new mining operations that had seemingly sprung up overnight. Thus the intrepid young girl left the family business entrusted to her brother and ventured forth for what she thought would be but a few short months.

Paewyn made her way to the mining camps uncovering ancient ruined statues depicting a long lost civilization — some said the region was once inhabited by one of the Eld Gods. The rumors of newly discovered ruins turned out to be false. However, on the day Paewyn was set to leave in disappointment, a half-starved human stumbled into the camp, rambling about a shattered tower and a massive two-headed monster. Those who cared for the traveler, clearly driven mad with thirst, dismissed his ramblings, but Paewyn, her mood soaring at the potential adventure, set forth into the wastelands instead, coming across The Living Tower with relative ease. There, Karthax offered what she desired most — treasure and adventure — in exchange for a bit of time within the tower.
This clever girl was a joy to debate when she came to the tower.  〄

{@b Roleplaying Paewyn Tealeaf.} Paewyn is generally quiet, preferring to watch and observe others rather than voicing her opinions. However, she is willing to offer her thoughts if prompted. She can come across as level-headed, perhaps even sarcastic (some might describe her as "sassy") once she becomes more comfortable around others. Despite only standing 5-feet tall, the human has a confident presence, and is sure in her abilities. Despite her chosen profession, Paewyn has a firm sense of loyalty once it is earned, viewing those who demonstrate their worth as family themselves. She has a protective side as well, and delights in a good joke — particularly with children. She is rather fond of orcs and knows them well (thanks to her time with her brother), and also well enough to know that not all take kindly to other races. Paewyn can be portrayed with the following phrases:

items: When describing how she came to The Living Tower:  "{@i I heard there might be treasure in some ruins within the wasteland from a rambling, delirious man who stumbled into the camp I was staying in. Others thought he was a lunatic, I thought there might be something to it...}"
When describing her interactions with Karthax:  "{@i That weird voice? Yeah, he let me come in here, promising me treasure and adventure if I had a peek around for a bit. Easy choice - here I am!}"

When describing the floor:  "{@i There are a bunch of orcs in here, and they seem to be a bit obsessed with their spirits. They just got here — I can hear them chanting sometimes, might be some sort of ritual. I thought I might go see, but figured I'd keep a low profile until I could figure out what they're doing.}"

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Rune
entries: When the characters arrive on Floor 1, read or read or paraphrase the following:

You are vaguely aware of powerful magical energies permeating your body as though your very essence is being ripped apart before being assessed and then painstakingly reassembled. To say the experience is uncomfortable would be a great understatement, and though you are only conscious for what might be a few moments, those moments are agonizingly long.
Your senses abandon you, leaving only the dark.

Slowly your senses return to you, starting with an intense bout of nausea that causes you to purge the contents of your stomach which is in such excruciating pain that you writhe upon the ground, whimpering in pain. You once again lose consciousness.

When you regain your senses once again, the pain in your abdomen has subsided to the point where you can function, and the nausea only reminds you of the aftermath of a particularly rowdy evening in a tavern that served questionable ale.
Nonetheless you are able to sit up and take stock of your surroundings.

You find yourself within a circular room, perhaps 40 feet in diameter. The dark stone walls appear to be identical to the stone ruins you entered but a few short hours ago. The shattered remnants of furniture - chairs, two tables, and what was once a 20-foot-long bench - lie strewn about haphazardly about the room. An arcane glyph on the floor that resembles the one near the pillar you just touched is silent and dark.

The wind whistles through arrow slits spaced evenly along the wall of the room - you appear to be in a tower overlooking the wasteland you recently traversed. From your vantage point you can see nothing but the blowing of dark sand across the barrens.

There is a single, closed door in one corner of the room. Numerous footprints have disturbed the fine layer of dust and sand that the blowing winds have carried through the arrow slits, otherwise the room seems to have been left undisturbed for quite some time.

Once the adventurers regain consciousness and stand, have them make a {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw. If they fail, the character makes Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws with disadvantage until they complete a short or long rest. Should they fail the save by 5 or more, they suffer one level of exhaustion.

A successful {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom (Survival)} check will indicate that, based on the settling of the disturbed dust, at least three distinct groups have recently been in this room: a single lone humanoid with small footprints (Paewyn Tealeaf), a band of six heavy-footed larger footprints (Dhugar Bloodsinger and five Orc Disciples of Blood), and three sets of footprints similar to the larger band (Druvok Steelhead and two Orc Scouts).

entries.name: 2. Hallway

entries: A long hallway 10 feet wide and 100 feet long greets you. What was once a fine red carpet has faded and is coated in a layer of dust - but for the multiple sets of footprints that lead in various directions. Aside from the dust the carpet is in remarkable condition, well preserved - clearly not even insects find the wasteland hospitable.
Sconces are silent, some containing unlit torches while others have been removed. Several closed sets of wooden doors line the hallway.
At the distant end of the hall you can make out what appears to be an armored figure.

Several torches have been removed by Dhugar Bloodsinger and Druvok Steelhead's bands. The two suits of armor at either end of the hallway are suits of half plate, ancient but serviceable. Each suit bears a spear held at attention and a shield in front of them.

entries.name: 3. Mess Hall
entries: A double set of wooden doors leads to an abandoned mess hall, which is also being examined by {@b Druvok Steelhead} and two {@b Orc Scouts}. On a successful {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom (Perception)} check listening at the doors, a character will hear faint murmurs of several deep voices talking to one another in Orc.
You open the doors and behold still more debris strewn about. Wooden tables and chairs have been destroyed as though the mess hall had been ransacked long ago.

Three large humanoid figures appear to be examining a cold stone hearth in the corner of this room turn to face you; you quickly idetify them as orcs as two of them begin reaching handaxes at their sides. Before weapons can be fully drawn, the third orc quickly places his large hand upon one of his companion's arms that was about to draw steel. Taking stock of you and your companions, the orc slowly raises a single finger to his lips, a clear indication to be silent.
Who you assume is their leader, a hulking figure with a crude steel breatplate and massive pauldrons, beckons you into the room, eyes wary.
At the leader's gesture, the other's hands slowly withdraw from their weapons and their stances relax ever so slightly.

Druvok Steelhead has been hunting for Dhugar Bloodsinger, and is silently exploring this floor with his party. They arrived a short time prior to the arrival of the adventuring party and are wary of alerting their quarry.

The orcs have no quarrel with the adventuring party, and will quietly summarize what brought them to The Living Tower — emphasizing that unlike the coward Dhugar Bloodsinger, Druvok and his smaller band hold honor in high regard and would avoid conflict — for now.

entries.name: 4. Larder
entries: The shelves in this room are bare. When the characters enter this room, read or paraphrase the following:

A small door off the mess hall leads to a small larder. Clearly the inhabitants of this tower would have once been well provisioned, yet now the room has been ransacked. There is nothing of value within this room.

Several mostly empty sacks of grain are piled in one corner, the few remaining kernels smell of mold and are covered in a black fuzz. Two large water barrels have been drained, their spigots wide open. Several casks have been placed in a corner, and when disturbed several mice rapidly scurry away — but even a glimpse of these tiny creatures tells you they are clearly unhealthy. Broken ceramics have been shattered and are unusable.

entries.name: 5. Southwest tower (Ballistae)
entries: When the characters enter this room, read or paraphrase the following:

A door leading from the larder opens into another tower. A trio of ballistae stand ready, wickedly barbed bolts loaded. Despite their age they were clearly well maintained, their mechanisms glistening with oil beneath a layer of dust. Between the trio, long crates contain a number of bolts, each as long as a full grown person.

Looking through the arrow slits, you see the ballistae have been positioned to guard a narrow pass to the west, which appears to be the only approach to the tower from that direction. The ballistae have been positioned to overlook the flat barren plain leading to the tower, and would no doubt have been a strong deterrent to an opposing force approaching the tower's walls.
Each ballista is on a cleverly designed wheeled platform that allows them to swivel or even roll to adjust the arrow slits through which they are poised to fire.

The ballistae are too large to move through the larder and mess hall. A successful {@b {@dc 14} Intelligence (Investigation)} check allows a character to assemble or disassemble a ballista in 1 hour. Otherwise, it takes 4 hours.
{@item Ancient Ballista|gp_karthax}
These Ballistae were constructed at my behest to guard the pass to my tower. They were never truly tested. 〄

entries.name: 6. Armory
entries: Through a set of doors on the west side of the hallway is a well-stocked armory.

Peering into this room, you see several well-stocked racks of weapons - though some have recently been removed based on the disturbed layer of dust. Clearly whoever was here made no attempt to conceal their presence.

All manner of weapons have been neatly stowed away — several heavy crossbows, their winch mechanisms well preserved, are in one rack. Beneath the rack lies a small crate with quarrels for the same. Several racks against the wall hold a dozen spears, and the remaining racks contain an assortment of longswords, greataxes, maces, halberds, warhammers, and a few shields.
While none of the weapons are magical, allow the adventurers to provision themselves as they see fit with any weapon of their choice — they will no doubt need it as they explore The Living Tower.

If Druvok Steelhead and his scouts are with the adventuring party, they will admire the weapons and remark that the spear blades and barbed crossbow quarrels somewhat resemble those used by orc clans long ago.

entries.name: 7. Meeting Room
entries: When the characters enter this room, read or paraphrase the following:

This room once housed important meetings — located within the interior of the tower, it is well protected from potential outside threats. Two benches sit on the north side of the room, and eight sturdy yet masterfully crafted chairs with faded leather seats are equally spaced around a long, wooden table.

Clearly a group has recently been through this room; the chair at the head of the table has been pulled back and the dust on the seat disturbed. Based on the layer of dust on the table, someone must have put their boots upon it.
Two sets of doors, one to the east and one to the north, have been shut. A series of footprints lead through the north door.

This room once hosted council meetings by the followers of Karthax who retreated here after being defeated in battle. It was used to plot potential defense of the tower should their enemies track them here, or as a base of operations from which to launch sorties against vulnerable supply lines.
A successful {@b {@dc 17} Wisdom (Survival)} check will also observe a single set of faint, smaller humanoid tracks leading through the east door.

entries.name: 8. Ruined Quarters
entries: Sand blows fiercely in this room, assaulting the eyes of creatures who enter.
A strong wind driven from the north east whistles through this room, carrying an abundance of sand and grit that assaults you the instant you open the door.

The room itself is bedlam — the remains of several wooden bunk frames have been completely shattered, and debris from a collapsed ceiling has buried more wooden frames under a mound of rubble. You have a clear vantage point to the ground, which is quite distant.
The obliterated section of the tower also leads to a tower in the northeast corner.
The character who enters the room first must make  a successful {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw or be blinded for 2 turns by sand blowing into their eyes.

Any attempts to escape The Living Tower descending to the ground below via rope fail, for Karthax's magic will prevent the rope from being long enough - and any creatures who attempt to leap are magically teleported back into the tower and find themselves back at the teleportation glyph (Area 1).

entries.name: 9. Ruined Northeast Tower
entries: Rubble litters the floor in this room. When the characters enter, read or paraphrase the following:

The wind continues to howl through the devastated remains of a tower. Tons of rubble have collapsed in this floor, and there is little of note - except, that is, for a small figure in dark leathers that is peering intently at something unseen within the rubble.
The human glances at you with suspicion, dark eyes wary. She slowly draws a dagger, but makes no threatening moves as her steady gaze meets and holds yours.

The northeastern tower has been ruined as well, wooden furniture buried beneath tons of rubble. An {@b Aldravex} is warily picking its way among the ruins, attempting to detect any precious metals, minerals, and gems that may be hidden within. Observing and attempting to catch it is {@b Paewyn Tealeaf}, who will initially regard the adventurers with suspicion, though she will immediately brighten if Druvok Steelhead and his scouts accompany the party — their solemn and dour moods lightening when she addresses them in the Orcish tongue.

entries.name: Aldravex
entries: An Aldravex is a tiny, squirrel-sized creature that resembles a deer, but with an additional set of forelimbs — making it an unusual looking creature indeed.

Originally descended from creatures native to a terrain of rock and earth, the aldravex has a particular fondness for consuming precious metals and gems, though in the absence of its preferred diet it is herbivorous. A single aldravex can consume a mass equal to 10 coins worth of metal or minerals in 10 minutes, making it a significant nuisance if one should make their way into a treasure horde. They are also quite shy and wary, relying on stealth and speed to escape predators.

Aldravex are quite harmless, even considered "cute" by some, which often results in the foolhardy capturing them and attempting to keep them as pets — until they gnaw through the metal bars of their cage.

Some thieves or other greedy individuals have been known to train Aldravex to seek out hidden treasure hoards, for they have an uncanny ability to find even the smallest amount of gold, no matter how well hidden.

entries.name: 10. Hallway
entries: The doors in the north wall of the meeting room lead to a second hallway, nearly identical to the first, but shorter. A set of doors open into the chapel (Area 11). There, Dhugar Bloodsinger has nearly completed a blood ritual to summon several {@b Orc Ancestral Spirits}.

entries.name: 11. Chapel
entries: The chapel is humble, as is the altar. Dhugar Bloodsinger and his party each ritualistically offer their own blood from slices in their arms, coating the Sanguarite Amulet. With a paean to their ancestors in an ancient orc dialect — taught only to the most ambitious and worthy orc ritualists — the sanguarite amulet is a vessel through which orc spirits may be communed with — or summoned to the Material Plane.

A set of  doors to the north of the hallway leads into a chapel, where worn and humble wooden pews on either side of a central path face a small shrine flanked by tall iron candelabras covered in wax.

While this room might once have been a place of worship, it has clearly been used for more sinister purposes: five large humanoid figures, while orcish in nature, seem unnatural; gangly creatures covered in red fur that has been stained with blood. They stand guard around a smaller hunched figure, back bent and deformed, clad in a humble hide cloak. From beneath his cowl, the orc's beady eyes glint with malice, seeming to flash the color of blood.

The altar at the end of the room has been...defiled. An amulet sitting upon the altar has been covered in blood — likely from the ritualists before you. The amulet, a golden band surrounding a ruby-like gemstone, is unlike anything you've seen before: while the outer edge of the gem is a bright crimson red, the center is black, completely devoid of color. The red of the gemstone pulses, seemingly growing more intense with each passing moment.
The hunched figure addresses you in a mocking tone:  "{@i Outsiders! Orcish land is not for you to poison and corrupt, it is for our people. The spirits of the ancestors shall protect our lands!}"
The figure turns back toward the altar and begins chanting in an orcish tongue, but in a dialect that is unfamiliar given your knowledge of the language.
The five reddish orcs slowly fan out, blood-caked claws extending from their hands.
If Druvok Steelhead is with the adventurers, add the following:

The hunched and deformed figure looks up once more, voice dripping with disdain:  "{@i Brother...your cowardice and refusal to protect your people might yet lead them to ruin. Never you mind though, where your strength surely fails, my cunning will prevail!}"

The five {@creature orc disciple of blood|gp_karthax|Orc Disciples of Blood} will protect Dhugar Bloodsinger's ritual, which takes 2 more rounds to complete. Should Dhugar maintain concentration on his ritual (as if he is concentrating on a spell), at the end of his second turn in combat, 2d4 {@creature orc ancestral spirit|gp_karthax|orc ancestral spirits} will appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet of Dhugar, loyal to him, and attack the adventurers.

entries.name: 12. Ruined Northwest Tower
entries: The northwest tower can be accessed through a locked door in the chapel. The lock itself requires a {@b {@dc 15} Dexterity (Thieves Tools) check with thieves' tools to pick, or it can be forced open with a successful {@b {@dc 17} Strength} check.
Read or paraphrase the following:
The ceiling of this tower has also collapsed, yet some weapon racks against the southern wall remain intact and bear arms. The faint glint of gold beneath some of the rubble catches your eye...

This was once a treasure chamber, but has since collapsed. Much of the treasure has been consumed by the Aldravex over the time it has been on this floor, accessing the room from a small hole in the wall behind the armor in the second hallway.
The rubble may be cleared away in 1 hour, granting access to two chests. Each contains ancient gold coins bearing the face of a bearded man (250 gp per chest).

The weapon racks lining the south wall of this room contain more weapons, yet some are of higher quality. Among them are two silvered shortswords, and a mastercraft spiked mace. A successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Arcana)} check indicates is magical ({@item mace, +1}).

entries.name: 13. Captain's Quarters
entries: Behind the defiled altar, a locked door accessible with a {@b {@dc 15} Dexterity (Thieves Tools)} check with thieves' tools to pick or forced open with a successful {@b {@dc 17} Strength (Athletics)} check opens into the captain's quarters.

Unlike the quite functional and simple rooms elsewhere in this tower, this room is small, but almost luxurious by comparison. A lounging chair beckons invitingly, an empty silver cup resting on a side table as though its master had stepped away for only a few moments.

A writing table against the wall opposite the chair also appears to be waiting for a scribe to return, a notebook — its pages yellowed with age — lies open to a blank page while a quill and ink pot rest unspilled nearby. A bookshelf that smells of rich mahogany resides next to the desk. It is neatly organized, and contains a number of weathered, leather-bound books.
Additionally, a single book rests on a raised pedestal in the corner, pages open to what appears to be an ancient map.

The open book on the pedestal contains a map of what appears to be a swampy region flanked by a mountain range to the east, north, and west. A successful {@b {@dc 17} Intelligence (History or Investigation) or Wisdom (Survival)} check will indicate the mountain range resembles that which the adventurers view from the arrow slits of each tower — a narrow mountain pass to the southwest, for example, being guarded by the ancient ballistae. The now barren wasteland in which The Living Tower resides was once a flourishing swamp, home to countless species of flora and fauna. The Great Cataclysm raised an imposing volcano and laid waste to the region. This map reflects the region prior to this time, and was used by Karthax's followers to plan their defense of The Living Tower should the need arise. It also contains information on the documented life in the area — including a reference to the greatest of all swamp predators, the hydra.

The bookshelf contains books on politics, navigation, tactics, and logistics as well as blueprints for the ballistae and other such documents. If a character spends more than 15 minutes leafing through the books and makes a successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check, they also discover 1d6 scrolls of the following spells (in order): {@i aid, bless, cure wounds, dispel magic, lesser restoration}, and {@i protection from evil and good.}
The open book on the table is completely empty. However, when the characters search the pages, read the following:

The pages of this notebook appear blank - quite odd, considering the quill and ink nearby. Leafing idly through the pages, searching for anything of importance, you pause at one page. Words slowly begin to appear upon it, in elegant calligraphy:  "{@i You have proven worthy of exploring further into The Living Tower.}"
A wave of amusement washes over you. With a shock, you realize that the tower has been watching you...the whole time.

entries.name: Completing this Floor
entries: This floor is completed once the characters read the blank pages of the notebook on the writing table in the captain's quarters as described above. After they have, also read the following:

The omniscient presence that you realize has been examining your every movement carefully — the voice, Karthax, who spoke to you on the ground floor — presses against your senses. The pressure on your skull grows, causing you to clasp your hands to your head in pain. Magical energy once again begins to permeate your body, and your head pounds relentlessly.
This is your last memory, as your vision fades accompanied by an amused chuckle of anticipation.
{@item Sanguarite Amulet|gp_karthax}

I have retained the first floor exactly as it was constructed and inhabited by my followers millennia ago. Alas, those few mortals who remained loyal to me have long since perished, yet I retain their memories within these walls!
Few who enter my tower have made it past this point. I am impressed...  〄

entries.name: Background
entries: Ettins are hardly known for either their personal hygiene or for their charming and engaging social skills. Ettins in particular are solitary creatures, perhaps due to the tendency of their two heads to endlessly bicker with one another, often descending into crude shouting matches littered with name-calling and insults between each other, let alone with any nearby beings who have the misfortune of hearing such relentless bickering. However, they have been known to engage with other creatures such as ogres who, either due to their lack of wit, care, or hearing, are able to tolerate the presence of an ettin.

While predominantly boorish and crude, on rare occasions, an ettin is born with a rare gift: that of a greater intelligence (at least in one head), and even more rarely, of a limited ability to manipulate magical energies. Born in a den littered with cracked bones sucked dry of marrow and with animal hides strewn about, one such rare ettin had the double fortune of having a mother that actually had an inkling of maternal instincts. Their mother named the obviously more intelligent head Krul, for this male head appeared to be much more cruel than the typical ettin, and the more typically dense and unintelligent second head Thunk, after the sound a club makes upon impact.

As a young ettin, their mother recognized that Krul'Thunk - or more specifically Krul - had a unique curiosity and could interpret the markings on the inside of the cave in which they lived for a time.

While most ettins hunt only wild game to provide to their offspring until they are able to hunt for themselves, Krul'Thunk's mother instead began hunting humanoids not for food, but rather for the flimsy "books" they sometimes carried. Thus Krul was not only provided for in terms of food, but also with knowledge. One such book happened to be an unfortunate wizard's spellbook, and by the time Krul'Thunk was old enough to hunt for themselves, Krul was also able to cast some simple magic spells.

Krul, ever curious and thirsty for more of this power they seemed to be able to control, constantly kept Thunk engaged with the promise of more "shiny things" pilfered from other humanoids. Thus they hunted smaller, weaker humanoids, in particular wizards, sorcerers, or anyone who looked like they might have books on their person. Krul learned more, and Thunk was well fed - both heads were content. They even took additional companions, for ogres in particular seemed to almost enjoy being told what to do by Krul.

In their wanderings, Krul's magical attunement grew, and Krul'Thunk was eventually drawn by sheer happenstance to The Living Tower. Promised by Karthax as many books as Krul could read in exchange for their service within the tower, Krul'Thunk settled within one of the lower floors where Krul could constantly read and experiment with their magic, and Thunk would be endlessly entertained both with visitors to The Living Tower as well as by Krul's sometimes spectacular failures at manipulating arcane energies.

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: Adventuring can sometimes be a dark and sinister affair. As we touch on some rather difficult and even gruesome stories in The Living Tower, we felt it important to add a touch of comedy to it as well - and a cantankerous, argumentative ettin and their minions seemed like the perfect fit. We envisioned both outright comedy in roleplaying Krul'Thunk and their ogre minions, as well as countless jokes about mutton and counting sheep.
Despite this humor, there are several valuable and noteworthy events and findings within this floor that bear further discussion:

items: Within the hidden "library" on this floor (area 10), if a character spends long enough they will come across an old tome titled "Ere Cataclysmae - A History of the Gods" which, while faded and crumbling from mishandling by clumsy ettin fingers, contains valuable lore about Karthax and the Great Cataclysm.
A single page torn from an obviously ancient book refers to the nine "Eld Gods" as beings of great power who brought both darkness and light to the realms of mortals.

Several sheets of parchment have crude inscriptions in orcish that contain information to manipulate magical energy and cast the spells described as "Krul's Motes of Fire", "Krul's Unrefined  Fireblast", and "Krul's Permanent Polymorph" - feel free to incorporate these or completely remove, but they do add a bit of fun to the adventure.

entries: We also suggest including some of the following into this floor - but strongly encourage you to be creative and have fun with it.

items: Bhargun Ironfoot could accompany an adventuring party through The Living Tower. As a strong warrior, his aid could prove invaluable.

The ten human steadholders who have been polymorphed into sheep are here as fodder for an assault on Krul'Thunk and the ogres - there are several ways they could be transformed back to their human selves, such as by a {@i dispel magic} or {@i lesser restoration} spell, which a Game Master could include in Krul'Thunk's library.

Krul, being ever curious about magic users, could take a particular liking to one particular member of an adventuring party. Likewise, Thunk might enjoy constantly attempting to goad a warrior into a contest of strength.

It is unlikely a party of 2nd to 4th level (which this floor is designed for) could overwhelm Krul'Thunk and the ogres - hence the large number of steadholders to support an attack. Should the battle go very poorly, the ogres and Thunk could get in each other's way and attack each other out of frustration.

As an added element of humor, Bhargun and the ten humans, as their ability scores are replaced by those of a sheep, could retain some sheeplike-characteristics - such as a fondness for rolling about in hay or mindlessly agreeing with or following others.

entries.name: Krul'Thunk, the Ettin Magus
entries: Krul'Thunk is a hulking, 10-foot-tall ettin clad in tattered hides and the scavenged remains of scale and chain armor clumsily cobbled together with bits of hide. Their two heads have personalities that are almost always completely at odds with one another. Creatures who encounter Krul'Thunk often hear (and smell) the ettin magus before they see them, as Thunk is nearly always yelling at Krul for some perceived slight (which is more than often accurate) in vulgar terms with a deep, slow voice. By contrast, Krul speaks much more quickly, in a higher-pitched nasal tone. Being much, much more intelligent than Thunk, Krul outwits his other half with ease, confusing the dim-witted but aggressive head with any number of distractions such as Thunk's favorites: a meal or a good clubbing.

Thunk's personality is that of a common bully: hit first, ask questions later. He speaks slowly using very simple, crude language. Thunk wears a crudely stretched horned helmet, clearly torn from the head of some unfortunate warrior. From beneath this helmet, his red, beady eyes frequently squint with malice, particularly when attempting to concoct something vaguely resembling "a plan." His face bears countless burn marks, his scraggly facial hair singed in places thanks to the threats that Krul sometimes follows through with, or the result of Krul's frequent tinkering with magic.

Thunk bears a large tree branch fashioned into a massive club that has been adorned with rusted blades gruesomely coated in blood and dried brain material. If annoyed with his other half, Thunk will use his arm to shove particularly vile materials (such as dirt or sheep excrement) in Krul's face - if particularly vexed by his counterpart, he may even punch Krul.

Thunk does get along particularly well with Urk, Grum, and Krunk, ogre visitors who somehow made their way to this floor - perhaps thanks to Karthax to provide company for the dim-witted Thunk, or perhaps merely for Karthax's amusement.

{@b Roleplaying Thunk.} Thunk is aggressive and does not fear warrior visitors to this floor. In fact, he may attempt to assert his dominance by challenging visitors to feats of strength or eating competitions. However, due to the powers wielded by Krul, Thunk is quite wary of magic users, particularly if he is uncertain of their capabilities. Thunk greatly prefers to let Krul deal with these types. Thunk can be voiced as follows:

items: When addressing other humanoids:  "{@i Yous come to play with Thunk! Good! I is bored....}"
When irritated at Krul:  "{@i Krul! Me don't like you much...}"
When particularly angry at Krul (as he shoves his other half):  "{@i Now yous done it brudder! Go way!}"
When uncertain or scared of magic being cast (shuddering or turning away):  "{@i Stop with them words! I don't likes them!}"
When hungry:  "{@i Good time for Thunk to be eatin!}"
When angry:  "{@i Time for smashing puny littlings!}"

entries: Krul, by contrast, is calculating and unusually intelligent for such a crude-looking being. As his name suggests, Krul is also quite cruel and will often use visitors to their floor as guinea pigs for his magical experimentations and explorations. In particular, Krul is quite fond of polymorphing visitors into sheep, which has an added bonus of providing a somewhat steady supply of mutton for the ettin and their ogre minions, Urk, Grum, and Krunk. Krul has a particular fondness for fire as well, and his eyes at times appear to blaze, particularly when angry or impatient.

Krul does, however, yearn for more intelligent conversation than that of Thunk or the ogres. Thus he will often eagerly engage with visitors, seeking to hear news of the outside world or even inquiring about arcane facts. Krul will barter for books or knowledge, but if denied will simply use Thunk and the ogres to coerce visitors. While visitors sleep, he frequently polymorphs warriors and pens them in with the other "sheep" while denying any knowledge of what happened to the individual to their companions. Clearly the concept of "counting sheep" or even "counting" is beyond the abilities of even the most intelligent of ettins.

Krul keeps Thunk, Urk, Grum, and Krunk in line through a healthy dose of fear. A few trivial flickers of magical flame is more than enough to send the ogres cowering and Thunk pleading not to get burned.
Krul has, through his own cleverness, been able to create several unique spells that are crudely written on parchment and carelessly scattered throughout this floor.
Unlike Thunk, who cares not one bit about Karthax and hasn't the memory to recall why, or for how long, they will be in service within The Living Tower, Krul will articulate the following:

items: Krul was drawn toward an unknown source of power - he couldn't understand it, nor can he articulate it well, but it relentlessly drew him to it.

The tower offered knowledge and power in exchange for time within The Living Tower. Krul frequently grows bored as a result, but has used the time wisely to develop a number of crude, if effective, spells.

entries: {@b Roleplaying Krul.} Krul is clever and intelligent, but also insecure. Knowing Thunk can easily bash most opposing warriors into submission, Krul is more wary of magic users. In particular, Krul is both curious and fearful of those who seem more intelligent and knowledgeable of the arcane - thus he will attempt to barter or negotiate for their knowledge and books, or failing those approaches, use Thunk and the ogres to coerce magic user's cooperation. Krul speaks in a nasal tone, and can be voiced as follows:

items: To visitors on the floor:  "{@i Ahhhhh...newcomers to welcome! We hope you like mutton!}"
If attempting to negotiate or plead for books or knowledge:  "{@i Come, we only want to learn....look at what I have to put up with here.}" (gestures to Thunk and the ogres.)
If annoyed with Thunk (eyes glinting ominously with fire):  "{@i Brother, you are starting to annoy me....}"
If angry with Thunk or the ogres, screeches in a shrill voice (as if casting a spell):  "{@i Now you've really annoyed me! Grumcrumsh, smrucash....}"
If intimidated or confronted:  "{@i Now we don't want crushed skulls.....Thunk likes those....or do we?}"

entries.name: Ogres: Urk, Grum, and Krunk
entries: Three 9-foot-tall ogres (Urk, Grum, and Krunk) are particularly dim-witted (even more so than Thunk), who somehow found their way to Krul'Thunk's floor — even though they can't really recall how. They are subservient to Thunk, whom they respect and follow due to his strength, while they fear displeasing Krul. In particular they dislike fire, as Krul's many experiments with minor incantations have left them with many painful burns.

All three ogres are brutish and gluttonous, like all of their ilk. They spend their time arguing over the choice parts of sheep carcasses or over the meager loot pilfered from visitors to this floor. They are smelly, easily manipulated, and particularly unintelligent - even for ogres. That said, if angered they are also indiscriminate in their violent outbursts and will just as soon attack one another as they will an enemy unless kept in check by the blunt threats of Thunk and the more veiled, suggestive ones of Krul.

{@b Roleplaying Urk, Grum, and Krunk.} Even less intelligent than Thunk, the three ogres have no idea how they came to The Living Tower or how they got to this floor in particular. They have zero goals other than to eat and play crude games with one another or with visitors, such as playing catch with rather large rocks. They can be portrayed as follows:

items: To Thunk, whom they defer to out of respect (such as being told to go fetch or feed the sheep flock):  "{@i Yah Thunk. I go do that.}"
To Krul, whom the defer to out of fear:  "{@i No, no! No ouchy fire sparks! Please!}"
To visitors, whom they regard as both with curiosity and as potential playthings:  "{@i You look strong. Want play with rock?}"

entries.name: Bhargun Ironfoot
entries: A dwarven warrior who found his way to this floor several weeks ago, Bhargun Ironfoot was transformed into a sheep by Krul and has somehow survived, possibly as he is the stockiest, stringiest, and leanest sheep in the pen. He has witnessed several groups enter this floor, who in turn each sat with Krul'Thunk and the three ogres for a meal, only to have new sheep join the flock each morning. One by one, each individual was interrogated by Krul before being polymorphed and joining the herd.

As a sheep, Bhargun seems to have particularly disdainful and angry eyes, unlike the rest which appear quite skittish and easily frightened. He will often be found at the front of the pen, bleating and calling angrily at Krul'Thunk or the ogres. Bhargun does not fear death, as he has resigned to his fate — though he is tired of waiting for it and would rather have it over and done with as opposed to watching Krul'Thunk and the ogres consume yet another sheep — and watching their disturbing table manners.

If transformed back into his normal self, Bhargun is dour, gloomy, and a dwarf of few words. He prefers to let actions (such as the swing of his hammer) speak louder than his words, and he generally does not have much patience for others. Nonetheless, he is loyal and a strong fighter. His party stumbled across The Living Tower, entered (he is uncertain who bargained with Karthax and for what - but he is quite angry, in general, at this fact), and only has knowledge of this floor.

Bhargun, if asked about the stonework of The Living Tower, will be able to describe it as something he has never seen. Ancient volcanic rock and granite yes, but a faint pulse courses through it as though it contained some living essence within.

{@b Roleplaying Bhargun Ironfoot.} Bhargun Ironfoot is stubborn, suspicious, and somewhat bitter at whomever of his former companions bargained with Karthax for entry. If asked who accompanied him, he will simply grunt, shrug, and state "doesn't matter. They're ogre latrine material now." Bhargun can be portrayed as follows:

items: As a sheep, if Krul'Thunk or the ogres approach (aggressively bleating):  "{@i BAAA!! MEHHHHH!}"
As a sheep, if another humanoid approaches, he will regard them suspiciously, but offer rather grouchy sounding calls:  "{@i Mrreehhh, Baa baa.}"
As a dwarf, he will very aggressively attack Thunk in particular, and the ogres as his second choice:  "{@i You damned foul beasts! Taste MY axe for a change, filthy cretins!}"
As a dwarf, to visitors to this floor:  "{@i Hrmph. Not sure how you've survived these cretins. But you seem good enough folk. Aye, I'll help ya.}"

entries.name: Human Steadholders
entries: Nine human steadholders (Alfred, Arnald, Birgit, Danae, Emad, Enno, Jörg, Katrin, Lis, and Otwin) were lured to The Living Tower as their village had been ransacked by a band of orcs several days ago (see the first floor of The Living Tower for details). Their food supplies were decimated by the raiders, so they tracked the raiding party to The Living Tower and were offered food in exchange for entering. Food they found, but also ended up as food — polymorphed by Krul once he realized they had neither books nor knowledge of magic. The crude weapons they brought with them — spears, pitchforks, a large hammer — are found in area 7. Alfred, Arnald, Emad, Enno, Jörg, Otwin (male) and Birgit, Danae, and Katarin (female) are all frightened, but more than willing to launch a desperate assault on Krul'Thunk and the ogres. Lis is the name of a tenth recently slain and eaten sheep.
Much like Orcs, Humans fascinate me. Capable of great deeds of compassion and good, yet heinous evil as well.〄

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Glyph
entries: When the characters arrive on this floor via the glyph, read or paraphrase the following:

An intense, magical aura causes an abundance of static and the occasional bolt of electricity to send shocks through your limbs. Your arms and legs twitch uncontrollably and quickly fall numb, causing you to lose control and drop whatever you were holding. To your astonishment, your items quickly levitate beside you, a faint nimbus of energy encompassing them - your last sight before your eyes roll back in your head and you lose consciousness.

The first thing that greets you is an intense wave of sickness, and you quickly roll to one side to purge the meager contents of your stomach. The sensation quickly fades, however, and you quickly regain your senses. You find yourself in a small room, runes in the rough hewn stone floor silent. The walls are crudely chiseled as though by some massive tool, but the stone reminds you of a naturally occurring cave. The ceiling, 15 feet above, is inconsistent; small stalactites and outcroppings visible above. The air is dry, warm, and smells both dusty and with the slight hint of decay.

There is nothing unusual in this room other than what is described above. A long, winding corridor leads away into the central common space of this floor. As the characters proceed along this route, read or paraphrase the following (just before they round the bend leading to area 2):

As you round a bend, you begin to hear several voices. As you pause, you can make out at least three distinct voices - one slow and sonorous, one somewhat higher pitched and nasal, and one deep voice that bears a hint of fear in it.

The voices begin to escalate in both pitch and volume, before the sound of a small, sudden explosion causes you to jump and a yelp of pain and fear to echo down the hall. Immediately thereafter, the thud of footsteps can be heard moving away, and the voices settle somewhat.

entries.name: 2. Common Space
entries: The ettin and three ogres sit in this room, chatting with each other in broken common, with the occasional word or phrase spoken in giant mixed into their conversation. When the characters enter the room, read or paraphrase the following:

Peering around the corner, you spy a large crackling fire in a wide open room. Several large stumps are spaced around it, upon which several hulking figures sit and tear into the limbs of some unfortunate creature whose carcass has been roasting over the fire. Piles of bone litter are found strewn behind each stump, as though once licked clean of any remaining morsel the diners simply cast the bone behind them carelessly.
Despite recently having purged the contents of your stomach, you can't help but salivate at the scent of roast meat.

The giant creatures before you begin bickering again before one pauses and turns one of its heads toward you. Its nasal voice softly calls out:  "{@i Guests! Guests once more...you morons, the tower has sent us playthings...I mean, honored guests, once again. Let us welcome them!}"

Krul, who notices the adventurers first, is unsurprised and reacts as such, however, Thunk and the ogres, dimwitted as they are, act surprised and even excited by the new arrivals. They will heartily welcome the characters, offering to pull up rocks to sit upon or to tear a bit of mutton from the spit-roasted sheep. Massive, crudely carved cups of ale (very strong, but of very poor quality) are offered insistently.

The ogres and Thunk will take a fond liking to any strong-looking warrior type, and ask them to tell stories while boasting of their own strength and challenging them to various competitions - lifting massive rocks which no Medium-sized creature could lift, engaging in arm-wrestling and the like. Thunk and the ogres are easily manipulated and impressed, while Krul remains mostly silent, cunning eyes observing the newcomers.
In addition, a bonfire sits in the middle of the room, which spreads bright light 10 feet around the fire and dim light outward an additional 30 feet.

After some time spent engaging, Krul will beckon to a random magic user to come sit closer to him and ask if they have any books — exchanging the story of Krul'Thunk's arrival in the tower for any book (such as a spellbook). Krul will initially be pleasant enough and eager to learn from the being. Thunk, on the other hand, will largely ignore any such exchange, and even make crude gestures about Krul behind his other half's turned head.
After a short time, paraphrase the following:
The massive, two-headed giant rises, the obviously more intelligent head declaring:  "{@i We need more mutton! Urk, your turn. Fetch us a morsel!}"

This directive causes immediate complaining from the ogre identified as Urk and an immediate round of bickering between the ogres. This is quickly settled when one hand of the ettin reaches out, palm up, and a burst of intense flames erupts within the palm. With a sudden yelp, Urk leaps up and toward a darkened corner of the cave, where the sudden panicked bleating of sheep greets him. Muttering and grumbling is heard before the ogre emerges from an enclosed pen you can faintly make out beyond the fire, a rather rotund looking, urgently bleating sheep under its arm. The ogre plods toward another corner. Shortly thereafter, the dull thud silences the panicked calls of the sheep, and it is just another minute or so before a fresh meal is being turned on the spit.
The ogres and the head known as Thunk eagerly turn their attention to the spit, arguing over the best seasonings to use this time, to which drool seeps from the corner of their mouths.
Allow the characters to question the ogres and Krul'Thunk for a time. Eventually they will get bored and tired - at which point Krul will declare:
"{@i Daww...the little ones look tired. Let them sleep! Time enough for more eatin' tomorrow!}"

The ogres and Krul'Thunk will retire to area 8, allowing the characters the opportunity to either rest or explore this floor. Due to his two heads, any attempt to attack the ogres or Krul'Thunk while they rest is doomed to fail.

Once the characters rest, Krul will utilize his {@i sleep} spell to send whomever is standing watch into a peaceful slumber and ensure the other adventurers don't rouse before polymorphing the strongest warrior and placing them in the pen. Krul will deny any knowledge of what happened to them, lying and simply blaming the tower for taking guests away as soon as they arrive.. A successful {@b {@dc 13} Wisdom (Insight)} check will reveal Krul is lying.
If the adventurers are clever, they will notice the same number of sheep as the night before...

entries.name: 3. Latrine
entries: If the characters foolishly want to investigate this room, read or paraphrase the following:

A particularly vile stench wafts from a corridor that leads to something any who know ogres would be shocked to see - that of a bath (if a crudely constructed metal tub containing filthy, stagnant reeking water could be called such). Clearly the inhabitants of this floor might, at least on rare occasions, attempt to not be as disgusting as they currently smell.

Even more foul smelling is the scent emanating from a pair of rickety, half collapsed latrines. If there were insects in the tower, no doubt this room would be filled with their buzz, but there is an unusual silence here - except for the occasional bursting bubble that can be heard within one of the latrines.

The stench of this room lingers on the palate long after a character leaves this room. If a character spends more than 1 minute in this room, they must succeed on a {@b {@dc 15} Constitution} saving throw or make any Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws with disadvantage until they complete a long or short rest due to the nauseating effects the stench in this room has on them.

entries.name: 4 & 5. Sheep Pen
entries: When the characters investigate this room, read or paraphrase the following:

Enclosed within a large, crudely constructed wooden pen are eleven sheep of various sizes. The floor of the pen is littered with straw, and two troughs (one containing grain, one fresh water) are clearly frequented. Some of the sheep are resting, others look at you with mournful, almost pleading eyes. One particularly stocky sheep practically glares at you from right up against the pen. This one seems particularly cantankerous - for a sheep.
The ogres clearly care more about the sheep than they do about their own hygiene.

The ten steadholders and Bhargun Ironfoot were permanently polymorphed into sheep. Lis, who was slain and consumed the night before, was replaced by whichever character was polymorphed during the last night. This character is sleeping in the back of the pen (area 5) as a result of the aftereffects of Krul's {@i sleep} spell.

A successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Nature)} or Wisdom (Animal Handling) check will indicate these sheep don't behave like common livestock - and that their eyes seem uncharacteristically intelligent (for sheep).

The sheep may be returned to their original forms using a {@i lesser restoration} or {@i dispel magic} spell - if not available to a group of adventurers, they could be found in area 10. Casting one of these spells would affect all of the sheep, who eagerly group toward any character making somatic gestures or reading from a scroll.

If released from their pen, hilarity may ensue as the ogres round up the clearly agitated and early escaping sheep — an ogre may accidentally trip and fall on one, or inadvertently strike another — there are many opportunities for a surprise attack against the ogres if the characters are unable to determine the sheep are polymorphed humans (and a dwarf).

If polymorphed back into human form, the steadholders will tear apart the pen, using the sharpened wooden poles as spears, grabbing a crudely made pitchfork used to add hay into a trough for feed, and grabbing an axe or hammer (which the ogres use from time to time as a meat tenderizer) from area 6.

entries.name: 6. Butcher Block
entries: When the characters investigate this room, read or paraphrase the following:

A sturdy butcher's table, stained with blood, sits neatly against a wall of the cave this floor resembles. A nearby stump has an axe firmly embedded within, and a large hammer - used as a meat tenderizer perhaps? - also lies nearby. Yet another pile of discarded bones lies in an alcove.
The greataxe embedded in the stump can be removed with a successful {@b {@dc 10} Strength} check. There is nothing else of interest in this area.

entries.name: 7. Store Room
entries: When the characters investigate this room, read or paraphrase the following:

This room, unlike others on this floor, is surprisingly tidy (if tidy were a word used to describe an ogre's attempt at cleaning). A central table contains the crude remnants of what might be described as "cooking" - maybe an attempt to spice up a tasty, but otherwise unexciting diet?

Crates of grain, brewing supplies, and barrels of ogre-brewed beer are abundant. Dried onions hang from stalactites in bundles. It appears there is at least some sense of culinary taste - no doubt from the clearly more refined Krul.
Ah ogre's brew, not even a deity is immune to the effects of such a hideous concoction! It's a miracle the species has survived this long... 〄

entries.name: 8. Den

entries: A well-trodden-upon lion pelt welcomes visitors into this room. Three piles of straw, covered in tattered blankets, are clearly where the three ogres collapse after a day of eating mutton and drinking their brew. A rather neater pile in the corner is covered in hides and somewhat neatly rolled blankets. A sturdy chest is set against one wall of the cave.

The chest is unlocked, but contains disappointing contents - a handful of copper coins (25 cp), some crude personal effects like a rapier which serves as a toothpick, and several more carved wooden cups.

One of Krul or Thunk is awake at all times, but Krul may feign being asleep to see what visitors to this floor do. Thunk sometimes sleeps, particularly if satiated with mutton or ale (a rare occurrence for such a ravenous creature). The ogres' snoring is almost as loud and obnoxious as their bickering with one another.

entries.name: Ogre Brew
entries: {@i A particularly pungent, crude ale concocted by an ogre, a creature that consumes a mug of ogre brew must succeed on a {@b {@dc 10} Constitution} saving throw or be blinded for 5 minutes. Each effect is additive and the DC for the saving throw increases by 1 for each additional mug consumed and the duration of blindness doubles. If a creature consumes 3 mugs of ogre brew, they automatically make all ability checks and saving throws with disadvantage until they complete a long or short rest.}

entries.name: 9. Krul's Alchemy Lab
entries: A stone door, cleverly disguising the entrance to Krul's alchemy lab, is noticed by a creature with a passive Perception of 15 if they are within 10 feet of it, or with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation)} check. The door is locked, the keyhole disguised as a nook in the stone, and can be picked with a successful {@b {@dc 12} Dexterity (Thieves Tools)} check using thieves' tools, or it can be broken into with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics)} check. Breaking the door immediately alerts Krul'Thunk and the ogres if they are not incapacitated. They will be quite irritated and may beat characters if they do break the door. The ogres fear entering, knowing Krul has forbidden them from entering the alchemy lab. Thunk barely knows of its existence - whenever entering Krul uses a {@i sleep} spell to ensure his much more clumsy counterpart doesn't cause a potentially disastrous accident.

entries.name: Alchemist’s Error
entries: {@i Aptly named, alchemist’s error was discovered serendipitously by an apprentice alchemist’s error. By misreading reagent labels, rather than brewing a healing potion the apprentice alchemist created a thick, brownish poison that smells of decay. The potion's distinct appearance and smell makes it easy to identify, requiring a successful {@b {@dc 10} Intelligence (Investigation, Nature) or Wisdom (Medicine, Survival)} check. It is commonly used to lace bait and is lethal to small vermin such as mice, rats, and other pests, but can also be smeared on arrows, edged weapons, or traps due to it retaining its potency indefinitely. As it is both easy to synthesize and inexpensive, it is used by thugs and mercenaries. A creature exposed to this poison either by ingestion or injury must make a {@b {@dc 10} Constitution} saving throw. On a failed save it takes 3 (1d6) poison damage.}
Once the characters break in, read or paraphrase the following:

To your astonishment, behind the disguised stone door lies a methodically organized and tidy room. Multiple flasks and bottles are found across one workbench, most containing various reagents and on a second, a number of alchemist's tools - flasks, vials, odd glassware you don't quite recognize, and fine metal utensils are neatly organized. Against the wall are also several flasked liquids attached to yet more glassware - one amber and bubbling vigorously, one red shimmering liquid in a large flask, and one thick, brownish potion.

The glassware against the wall can be taken and used as an alchemist's supplies. The red, shimmering flasked liquid can be bottled with a successful {@b {@dc 12} Intelligence (Medicine)} check, and contains enough for four (4) healing potions - a creature that drinks one vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points (takes one action). The amber, bubbling potion is an explosive flask of Krul's Explosive Concoction.  The thick brown potion is a failed attempt at making a healing potion - and can be used as an alchemist's error poison. Both recipes can be found in Krul's library.

entries.name: Krul's Explosive Concoction
entries: {@i Created by Krul'Thunk, the ettin magus, this potion is a bubbling, clear azure concoction that is highly reactive. Upon exposure to air or any temperature greater than that of a humanoid creature, this potion will explode, dealing18 (4d8) fire damage to any target within a 10-foot radius of it. If the target is a creature, it must make a {@b {@dc 14} Dexterity} saving throw, taking half the damage on a successful save. If a creature fails its saving throw by 5 or more, the volatile fluid sticks to the creature and deals an additional 4 (1d8) fire damage at the start of the creature's next turn.}

entries.name: 10. Krul's Library
entries: The library is concealed behind a disguised door similar to the one hiding Krul's alchemy lab, except this door is trapped. If the door takes physical damage, is subjected to a forced attempt to open it, or the lock tampered with (a failed Dexterity (Thieves Tools) check), a burst of fire erupts from the door in a 10-foot cone in front of it. A creature caught in this blast cone must make a {@b {@dc 14} Dexterity} saving throw, taking 14 (4d6) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Similarly, Krul uses a {@i sleep} spell to ensure Thunk is asleep when they enter — the one time Krul forgot to do this, Thunk accidentally shredded one of the last known copies of a detailed history of the Eld Gods (the single page referring to the Eld Gods is all that remained of Thunk's clumsy attempt at opening the book.

Entering this room, you behold a sight one would never expect to use in the context of an ettin's belongings - the sight of books. A large writing desk, littered with scrolls, parchments, and a precariously tilted ink vessel are upon the desk. A large, but bow-legged chair (no doubt creaking under the weight of its frequent inhabitant) is also surrounded with a number of strewn about papers. Three bookshelves line one wall, and a half-constructed fourth bookshelf awaits completion. Books are scattered on the floor before the shelves, either awaiting something that might resemble "sorting" and "putting away" - concepts one would not regularly attribute to an ettin or ogre.

There are several notable important scrolls, books and papers within this room. At the GM's discretion characters may automatically find scrolls of either {@i lesser restoration} or {@i dispel magic} - both of which can be used to return the polymorphed sheep into their original forms, or also scrolls that allow a character to cast {@i Krul's motes of fire, Krul's permanent polymorph,} and {@i Krul's unrefined fireblast.} These spells are crudely written in Common on random scrolls in this room.
If a character spends 10 minutes sifting through, they find:

items: On an Intelligence (Investigation) check role of 10 or higher: a scroll of (randomly) {@i enlarge/reduce, Krul's motes of fire, rope trick,} or {@i scorching ray}
On an Intelligence (Investigation) check roll of 13 or higher, a single page torn from an ancient book that contains reference to Karthax and refers to the being as an Eld God.
On an Intelligence (Investigation) check role of 14 or higher, alchemical recipes for creating a healing potion, alchemist's error poison, or Krul's Explosive Concoction
On an Intelligence (Investigation) check role of 15 or higher: a scroll of (randomly)  {@i counterspell, glyph of warding, Krul's permanent polymorph,} or {@i Krul's unrefined fireblast}

entries: If a character spends at least one hour sifting through the library, they find the above scrolls or recipes, as well as a copy of "Ere Cataclysmae - A History of the Gods", which can be fully read in two weeks due to the unusual dialect of Common used in its writing.

entries.name: Ere Cataclysmae - A History of the Gods
entries: {@i This tome is clearly ancient and must be handled with great care, for many pages crumble to dust when touched. It is written in an old dialect of common, but after struggling by campfire and candlelight for two weeks you learn the following:}

items: The so-called Eld Gods were thought to have been travelers from another plane of existence.
There is some debate among historians if they are in fact gods at all or merely beings of great power who at first lorded over the mortal races of this world.
While their numbers at first were many, at some point only nine were left, and those nine were often at odds over their role in this world as well as how the mortal races should be treated.

At some point there existed a "Great Debate", in which some of the Eld Gods, predominantly those who viewed the mortal races as inferior, felt that it was their right to instill strict laws over the mortals lest their bloodthirsty nature overwhelm them. The other faction believed that free will was universal, and that the mortal races should be free to choose their own paths, for good or ill.
The motivations of the Eld Gods appear to have varied within these apparently opposing philosophies, from noble and altruistic to manipulative and arguably evil.

Many libraries and universities were founded in honor of the Eld Gods, as were many religions - many strict in their belief systems. At times robust debate was encouraged, at other times suppressed. The tome is unclear on timelines and details on this topic.
At some point, the wisest moderator of these two opposing groups was struck down by some unknown force, and the Great Cataclysm erupted (the author refers the reader to an upcoming work).

entries.name: Completing this Floor
entries: This floor is completed once the adventurers subdue Krul'Thunk, either alone or with the aid of Bhargun Ironfoot and the human steadholders. Karthax will not allow either Krul'Thunk or the ogres to be slain - once reduced to 0 hit points, any killing blow is immediately stopped by an unbreakable magical force, and a wave of displeasure washes over whomever attempted to land the final strike. Once defeated, read or paraphrase the following:

The sight of a 10-foot-tall, groveling, two-headed giant strikes you as somewhat ironic, given their intimidating physique. Nonetheless, you are unable to deliver a final blow. You sense a great deal of amusement directed toward the situation, combined with a hint of surprise - surprise perhaps that you and your companions have made it so far into this sentient tower.
A sickly feeling washes over you, now becoming unfortunately familiar. The hum of magical runes permeates your body, and you quickly lose consciousness.
{@spell Krul's Motes of Fire|gp_karthax}
{@spell Krul's Unrefined Fireblast|gp_karthax}

entries.name: Tattered Page
