entries: {@i A fragile page from an ancient tome, it has been torn and clumsily fused back together by vile magic. Many of the symbols and much of the writing have been lost, but you can make out the following:}

Karthax, Lord of De....., and master of thieves. Master assassins and gamblers alike would seek.................was opposed by Yvr......, Hammer of Might. Moderating these two, Sapi.....Lord of Wisdom and most revered by all who love nature......... Xyr..........and Master of Mysteries and Death......despite their differences, could agree........

entries.name: Background
entries: Long ago, a rather typical event occurred within the canopy of a dense and peaceful forest. A spider broke free of her egg, the first of a clutch of several thousand within the egg sac. Rather than drift away on a gossamer strand with the gentle breeze rustling the leaves of the forest, the ravenous hatchling began to feast on her still developing siblings until only she remained. This particular spiderling was unique in that her body was rapidly able to metabolize whatever it consumed and shift its physiology, adapting any beneficial genetic traits it encountered while discarding less beneficial traits. The spiderling wasn't aware its body was doing this, but as she consumed her siblings, she slowly became self aware.

The ravenous spider rapidly grew, and within her first season, had grown to the point where she was no longer content with consuming mosquitos and the odd juicy fly, but was weaving webs to catch sparrows, finches, and other small songbirds. When it was time for most spiders to lay their egg clutches and accept the inevitability of the cycle of nature, this spider was unwilling to do so. Her rapidly mutating genetics meant that the cellular decline that accompanied aging and ultimately death no longer applied. But the spider hid away during the winter, burying herself deep within a lair in the forest floor.
When she awoke, the spider was unimaginably ravenous and had grown even larger - her second season was spent hunting and consuming squirrels, hares, and other small game trapped by her webs.
By her fourth season, the spider was the terror of the forest, devouring deer and larger game. But all were of inferior genetics...until she encountered one of the creatures known as humans.

The first one the spider consumed was beyond delicious, and her body shifted countless traits that allowed the spider to develop a consciousness, and even a language. Thus she began hunting this most delicious source of information - until they began hunting her in return.

Unable to repel countless waves of her delicious but vicious favorite food, the spider — dubbed Sryytyl the devourer by these tender morsels (the spider quite liked that name) — was ultimately driven from the forest she called home to seek new hunting grounds.

This pattern continued for some time — seeking new hunting grounds with naive prey before being driven away by them. Finally, Sryytyl came across a newly constructed tower in the midst of a wasteland. Starving and somewhat weakened from a lack of prey, she climbed the tower, coming to a floor through which a lone window was magically being sealed. Sryytyl slipped within, unbeknownst to the powerful consciousness she felt within the magical walls of the tower.
A giant dwelled within — unintelligent, but rendered immortal by the magic of The Living Tower — the perfect source of endless nutrition for Sryytyl, now sealed within.
Sryytyl began to weave strands of genetic information, singing contentedly, for now was the time to create her brood.

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: Karthax highly dislikes spiders, mirroring the feelings of one of the authors of this book. The idea to have a mutated and rapidly evolving insect or insect-like species that has infested an area is the subject of countless books and video games, and we wanted to instill our own twist in this floor. What would happen if Sryytyl and her brood escaped from The Living Tower?
We envisioned several dynamics that could take place within this floor:

items: The floor is covered in the mutagenic lifeblood that has been created by Sryytyl and is pumped throughout the chitinous layer that coats this floor by the heart beat of the poisoned, comatose giant. Exposure to the mutagen could have any number of effects.
Countless small tunnels that allow the brood to squeeze throughout the floor allow opportunities for the brood to study or even ambush visitors to this floor.

Burn it with FIRE! Should the players light the webs present throughout the floor aflame, consider having it weaken the chitinous layer so heavy creatures have a higher chance of breaking through the floor.

Seldezar D'Lael is a ruthless, power-hungry individual who would love to capture Sryytyl to control, study, and replicate the mutagen - whether or not he is allowed to do so is an entirely different matter. Nonetheless, he is a potential source of lore behind The Living Tower, and a potential ally if the characters can stand him and Seldezar deems them worthy of his presence.

Perkas and Belda Greenbough are both a source of comic relief as well as a highly unpredictable duo. Their small size would allow them to explore the small tunnels carved throughout this floor by the brood, if they could be convinced. They don't think very highly of Seldezar.

Alyryne Do'Lyl provides a potential source of treachery as well as information, being resistant to the mutagen's effects thanks to her dark elf heritage. This makes her a source of curiosity for Sryytyl. While she can describe the layout of this floor if convinced to do so, she only knows legends of great spider gods - she has come to believe Sryytyl is one of them.
The half-digested humans (Chem, Jashul, and Lorelai) are merely distractions to add an element of horror and suggestion and the potential fate of those who become trapped in this floor.

Any of the NPCs (Seldezar, Percy, or Belda) would potentially be able to accompany a party of adventurers to another floor. However, none would be particularly reliable or loyal allies, so if they survive and do choose to accompany the party, be sure to have their motivations — lust for power and greed — in mind.

entries: I have beseeched many to rid my tower of this monstrosity, but none have succeeded. Yet!  〄

entries.name: Sryytyl, the Devourer
entries: Sryytyl the Devourer is a massive, spider-like creature that is capable of absorbing and adapting the traits of creatures she has consumed, which are then passed down to her offspring, thus rapidly evolving her brood into a more intelligent race of spider-like creatures. Over time, this ability has allowed Sryytyl to develop rudimentary language skills, which are accentuated with the clicks, screeches, and whistles that her mandibles inherently create.

As Sryytyl was driven from countless hunting ranges by humanoids over her existence before climbing and infiltrating The Living Tower, she has an inherent loathing for all humanoids, and views them as inferior beings with few redeeming qualities, but nonetheless worthy of potentially strengthening her brood through traits such as great strength, intelligence, or magical bloodlines. The exception is the unnamed giant whom Sryytyl keeps in a comatose state as both a constant source of nutrients and a pump for the lifeblood that flows within the chitinous substance that coats her lair. She is therefore quite protective of the still-living denizen of this floor, and if any creature attempts to harm the cocooned giant she will become enraged and engage the threat with all her might.
Sryytyl is inherently intelligent, having both hunted and been hunted by humanoids and other predators.

Thus she is reluctant to engage directly in combat, preferring to allow her brood to protect her. She will engage with adventurers only insofar as to gauge their threat — she may attempt to negotiate with stronger visitors to her lair by perhaps offering escape from The Living Tower (a false hope; Sryytyl in fact has neither the knowledge nor motivation to aid in another creature's escape), only to have her brood consume them in their sleep. Those she finds particularly interesting may be worth further study, but eventually all but her brood will be consumed and their traits selected or discarded for incorporation into her children.

The violet, mutagenic fluid (which Sryytyl has dubbed "the lifeblood") that is found throughout her lair serves as a nutrient transport mechanism, digestive fluid, and mutagen. Creatures with prolonged exposure to this substance begin to adopt random traits (see the Floor Overview) that may become permanent given enough time. Sryytyl frequently taps into the lifeblood, which allows her to sample the various strands of genetic information contained therein.

The rapid mutation rate of her offspring has allowed the development of a unique language shared by her and her brood, which may be understood by a creature under the effect of the {@i comprehend languages} or similar spell. Sryytyl tolerates the presence of Alyryne Do'Lyl, viewing her as an intriguing specimen for study both on humanoid behavior as well as on the effects of the mutagenic fluids that flow within Sryytyl's nest.

{@b Roleplaying Sryytyl.} Sryytyl's mind functions in ways alien to humanoids. She is by nature a predator and acts as such, yet sees value in observing prey, looking for strengths and weaknesses. She views her brood as an expendable resource along the path to harnessing genetic perfection. She can be portrayed with the following behaviors/phrases:

items: To adventurers, while studying them or negotiating:  "{@i Ahhhhh...what has the tower sent to my domain this day...?}"
To adventurers, while protecting the slumbering giant:  "{@i No! You cannot touch it, it is the lifeblood!}"
To her brood, in a series of screeches, clicks and whistles (if understood):  "{@i Come my offspring...we shall feast upon them and make them our own...}"

entries: Sryytyl knows little about The Living Tower and Karthax, nor does she particularly care. She views the tower as a haven and a source for her to perfect her brood, from which she will break free at a time of her choosing. Little does she know that Karthax resents her presence, as she has taken over the floor against Karthax's will. Karthax periodically sends visitors of sufficient strength to this floor to remove this annoyance, though none have succeeded so far and Sryytyl's brood is only becoming stronger.

entries.name: Sryytyl's Brood
entries: Sryytyl's brood consists of countless insect-like creatures that are fiercely loyal to her. The brood is comprised of creatures such as {@b broodlings}, which are immature offspring that may form {@b broodling swarms}. Broodlings mature in a matter of days into {@b spawn of Sryytyl}, which are spider-like creatures that randomly possess any number of human-like traits: humanoid teeth as opposed to fangs, spider limbs tipped with elongated, humanoid-like fingers, or humanoid-like eyes with jet black irises. The occasional {@b evolved spawn} tend to be smaller than the spawn of Sryytyl, but are capable of spitting venom great distances and may even possess rudimentary magical skills. {@b Mutated humanoids} are the last of her brood — occasionally, rather than digest and consume visitors to this floor, Sryytyl will test the effects of the mutagenic lifeblood on these humanoids, twisting them into grotesque insect-like shells of their former selves.
{@b Roleplaying the Brood.} Sryytyl's brood will speak amongst themselves in their limited language. Should they be understood, they might be heard chittering and clicking the following:

items: "{@i New food has come to us......the mother desires us to observe them...for now...}"
If protecting Sryytyl:  "{@i Protect the mother!}"
If attacking:  "{@i Feast, siblings! Do not let the food escape!}"
If withdrawing:  "{@i Patience, siblings...poison shall weaken them...}"

entries.name: Alyryne Do'Lyl
entries: A dark elf that has been trapped by Karthax within their tower, Alyryne Do'Lyl has been tolerated by Sryytyl and her brood. Descended from a line of elves that worshiped long-forgotten spider gods, Alyryne spent her youth paying homage to such entities. As part of the worship of these deities, Alyryne had been exposed countless times to the venoms of various deadly spiders, and each time survived. As a result, she both worships Sryytyl, even though she knows she will never be accepted as one of the brood, but also reviles and resents being Karthax's captive.

Prolonged exposure to the mutagenic fluids flowing within the chitinous substance coating surfaces of this floor over several years has led to a change in Alyryne's appearance, abilities, and personality. Alyryne has developed insect-like compound eyes that allow her to see in even the dimmest of lights, and she can sense the slightest tremors in the web network that permeates this floor. Two sets of vestigial and undeveloped limbs sprout from her sides, and from her tattered rags, a hairy and hardened exoskeleton can be seen developing.

Alyryne is treacherous and devious, and while often she avoids any confrontations with visitors to Sryytyl's domain, to gain the devourer's favor. She has manipulated other beings into the brood's webs — for a trapped feast is much preferable to Sryytyl than a feast that fights back.

{@b Roleplaying Alyryne Do'Lyl.} Alyryne speaks in a limited dialect of the Common tongue, and speaks Elvish passably. Her speech is punctuated by clicks and chitters that come from the mandibles that are slowly emerging from her mouth. She moves in an insect-like manner — one moment in a jerky, blindingly fast manner, the next slowly, selecting each movement with the utmost care so as not to send the incorrect signals via the web network to the brood. She might engage visitors in the following ways:

items: To newcomers on this floor:  "{@i Why.....why have you come to this most sacred of floors...?}"
If attempting to placate a show of strength:  "{@i We know...know of the way...out...we shall show you...}"
If attacking, Alyryne will shriek  "{@i The brood shall feast upon your fluids!}" or  "{@i You shall join with those who came before!}"

entries.name: Cocooned Humanoids: Chem, Jashul, and Lorelai
entries: Chem, Jashul, and Lorelai are recent human visitors to Sryytyl's floor. Trapped within webbing and encased in cocoons, they are barely alive and are slowly being digested. Tendrils of insectoid tissue permeate their bodies. They are barely capable of coherent speech, but will reveal the following:

items: They came with a group of five to find a lost family member, and somehow found themselves in this horrid place — but cannot remember how.
Chem and Jashul remember being bitten by a spider, and then all is seemingly a dream... they feel completely numb.
They remember images of a human...being dissolved...by the violet fluid.
If awakened, Lorelai will screech inhumanly, and amidst her crying gibberish the only thing that can be understood is,  "{@i It is coming! The BIG ONE is here!!}"

entries: If their cocoons are disrupted, read or paraphrase the following:

Cutting away at webbing encasing the wretched being before you, you are disgusted by the eruption of half-digested entrails that suddenly burst forth and fall into a sickening heap upon the floor. The eyes of the human glaze over as their last breath shudders from their lungs. As you glance away, you catch a glimpse of something writhing in the entrail heap before you...
A newly emerged {@b broodling} (75% of the time) or {@b broodling swarm} (25% of the time) will chitter for aid, summoning 1d4 {@b Spawn of Sryytyl} that arrives the next turn.

entries.name: Seldezar D'Lael
entries: Seldezar D'Lael is a human wizard who was drawn to The Living Tower by rumors of powerful magics contained therein. An incredibly vain and self-centered individual, Seldezar wears only the finest silk clothes befitting his ancient and noble bloodline. He is a handsome and charismatic individual (when he chooses to be) with dark skin and impeccable jet black hair. A nimbus of arcane power surrounds him, which more practiced magic users identify as merely an illusion he casts to impress others. His arrogance and vanity are only matched by his lust for power.

Seldezar paid handsomely to have the two swindlers Perkas and Belda Greenbough to accompany him to The Living Tower. Seeing yet another easy mark, they happily agreed, all the while poking fun at Seldezar behind his back. When "captured" by the brood, Seldezar merely sneered and accused them of being weak before striding away boldly into the depths of Sryytyl's lair.

Upon entering The Living Tower only a day or two ago, Seldezar was considered by Karthax as a potential solution to the problem of Sryytyl and her brood, and thus teleported him, Perkas, and Belda to this floor to challenge the creature. While initially revolted and repulsed by the inhabitants of this floor, Seldezar has come to recognize the potential power that could be harnessed by understanding the mutagenic effect of the lifeblood.

Seldezar envisions creating an army of mutated undead solely under his control, and thus is seeking to trap Sryytyl for study and experimentation. He will therefore attempt to manipulate any potential allies he encounters upon this floor toward this goal, but without revealing his true intent.
Seldezar knows the following things about Karthax, which he is reluctant to share (have characters make either {@b {@dc 13} Charisma (Deception or Persuasion)} check):

items: According to some of the ancient texts Seldezar has read during his studies, the name Karthax was associated with thieves, tricksters, and troublemakers.
Karthax is described in these texts as one of the "elder beings" — Seldezar believes this to mean one of the old gods.
Accordinging to historical texts, the tower, while remote, has existed for centuries. None who enter have been seen again — but he will no doubt be the first.

entries: {@b Roleplaying Seldezar.} Due to his arrogance and intolerance for others, Seldezar is an unpredictable individual and an unreliable ally. He will manipulate others towards his own goals without hesitation, and cast them aside just as easily. He can be portrayed as follows:

items: Sniffing in disdain at those before him:  "{@i This....}this{@i .....is what comes to my aid? Pah. Very well, what can you do to aid me?}"
If engaged in combat:  "{@i Don't just stand there fools, aid me against these abominations!}"
If encountering Sryytyl:  "{@i Ah.....the brood mother.....you will be mine! I must know your secrets!}"
If weak or dying:  "{@i The world is not ready to lose my talents...}"

entries.name: Perkas and Belda Greenbough
entries: Twin brother and sister halflings, Perkas and Belda Greenbough (they call each other Percy and Bell) are swindlers for hire who accompanied Seldezar D'Lael to The Living Tower. Seeing yet another easy mark, they happily agreed in exchange for a handsome reward, paid in full in advance. Throughout their travels to The Living Tower, they happily skimmed a little extra coin from Seldezar's purse whenever the vain wizard was distracted or sleeping.

The twins complement each other perfectly: Bell being an engaging, attractive, manipulative, and quick-fingered thief, while Percy, a talented illusionist and enchanter, cunningly pulls the strings from behind the scenes. Inevitably, both walk away from their targets with a healthy amount of coin while their targets somehow feel they've gotten the better part of the deal. As twins, they seem perfectly aligned with each other's motives and frequently interrupt one another as they finish each other's thoughts and sentences.

Neither Percy nor Bell care one bit for any being other than themselves, nor do they owe anyone their loyalty. They will just as happily slip a dagger into someone's back as they would share a tankard of ale with them. Both are utterly without fear, and share a morbid fascination with Sryytyl's lair and the creatures within - though their healthy sense of self preservation tells them escape from The Living Tower sooner than later would be wise.
They don't have any knowledge of Karthax, other than describing it in terms of what Seldezar has told them, which is next to nothing.

{@b Roleplaying Perkas and Belda.} When initially encountered, they appear to be cocooned in the brood's webs, but this is just one of their many illusory tricks - not so much to evade the brood, but more to escape from the annoying and insufferable wizard that got them into this mess. While they are chaotic, lighthearted, and comedic even in such a horrid environment such as Sryytyl's layer, they are still unpredictable and should be roleplayed as such. They can be roleplayed with the following examples:

items: If one is missing:  "{@i Hey! Have you seen (Percy or Bell)? They're gonna miss out!}"

When describing how they came into Sryytyl's lair:  "{@i We came in with that stuffy uptight wizard. Have you seen him? We got bored, so Percy made it look like the spider things wrapped us in cocoons. Even the critters couldn't tell it was fake!}"
If attacked by Sryytyl or her brood, they might choose instead to flee if faced with overwhelming odds before disappearing behind an illusion:  "{@i Yeah...we don't think so. Bye!}"

If describing the floor, they will shrug and state the following:  "{@i We've been here, I don't know...a day or two maybe? Long enough that stupid wizard really started getting excited for some reason. He's so annoying. But there are these creepy spider things all over...and the big one gives us the heebie jeebies!}"
If injured:  "{@i It's all fun and games...until some mutant spider decides we're lunch. Maybe it's time to find a way out?}"

entries.name: Floor Overview
1. Teleportation Glyph
entries: When the characters arrive on this floor via the glyph, read or paraphrase the following:

The crackle of magical energies causes each hair on your body to stand on end, and you can feel the blood pounding behind your ears as transparent ancient mystical symbols rise before your eyes. You reach out in wonder, only for your hand to pass through one of the symbols, before a wave of nausea overwhelms you. Your body becomes weightless and you begin to spin about rapidly, levitating above the ground. Consciousness slips from you as darkness descends.

As you slowly regain control of your senses and the nausea subsides, the first thing that assaults your senses is the overwhelming stench of must and rot — that and an almost oppressive heat and humidity that makes each breath a labor. Glancing about, you see the runes of power fade and the crackle of energy dissipate, and the glyph beneath you falls into silence. The walls and floor are covered with a thick, chitin-like surface. Beneath it you feel a slow, steady beat of fluid being moved beneath the crust, and in some places a faint violet glow can be seen, pulsing almost rhythmically. Only the teleportation rune remains free of this noxious surface. Above, countless webs are interwoven, some strands of the web nearly as thick as your finger.
A distant unearthly chittering immediately washes away any residual fatigue you may have felt as adrenaline pulses through your veins.

This room is unusually carved, approximately 20 feet by 20 feet, with a hallway leading out. Spiderwebs are found above, woven across the ceiling. Outside of the teleportation glyph, the floors and walls are coated in a chitin-like substance. In places a violet fluid, Sryytyl's mutagenic lifeblood, can be seen flowing beneath. If a character spends at least 10 minutes observing the flow of the liquid, it will discover that the pulse is rhythmic, approximately 1 beat per minute. As the characters begin to take note of their surroundings, read or paraphrase the following:

You sense a slight movement in a hallway leading out of the room toward what you think is the north - the glint of light reflects off of several sets of eyes as the movement fades out what you are able to perceive.

A pair of {@b broodlings} that have been watching the activated teleportation glyph have moved away upon seeing the arrival of new humanoids to this lair. One is hiding in the Tiny-sized tunnel just off the main hall. A {@b {@dc 17} Wisdom (Perception)} check or {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (investigation)} check will reveal the presence of the tunnel.
As the characters move into the hallway, read the or paraphrase the following:
The hallway you are following begins to branch: toward your left, the hallway widens and the violet glow seems more intense toward the right, only darkness awaits you.

Creatures weighing 200 pounds or more have difficulty moving on this floor. For them, the entire floor is difficult terrain (unless otherwise indicated) and each time they start their turn while standing on the floor, there is a 10% chance that they break through the chitinous layer and are exposed to the mutagenic lifeblood below. On a roll of 1 on a d10, the character must roll on the Acute Mutagen Exposure table.

entries.name: Author's Note
entries: Mutagen exposure is optional. Alternatively (or in addition to mutagen exposure), each time a character breaks through the chitin layer, they take 2 (1d4) poison damage.

entries.name: 2. Right Path
entries: The various cocoons and webs in this room are littered with clothing and the occasional degraded piece of metal — a rusted shortsword or helmet. If the characters head right, read or paraphrase the following:

The hallway to the right slowly opens into a spiderweb-filled room. The webbing appears relatively sparse, though the chitinous layer appears thicker than the hall you just passed through. Several cocoons are found on a slightly elevated level in the center of the room. As you gaze about, one of the cocoons moves slightly.
Chem is encased in the cocoon that stirred slightly upon the party entering the room. Should this cocoon be investigated, read or paraphrase the following:

The humanoid-shaped cocoon that just stirred trembles slightly as you approach, as though whatever is held within can sense your presence. Peeling the sticky webbing away from what you presume to be the head, you reveal a humanoid face of what once might have been a handsome male - but now appears horribly disfigured. One eye resembles a cross between a human and some insect, and is crusted shut. The wretched being's skin is beginning to resemble the chitin which coats nearly every surface of this room. The being's one human eye flutters open as the webbing is pulled aside, and a faint groan emanates from their lips.
Another small tunnel leading to Room 4 may be discovered with a {@b {@dc 17} Wisdom (Perception)} check.

entries.name: 3. Left Path
entries: This room contains a web-covered lair. If the characters head left, read or paraphrase the following:

The hallway to the left opens to a room illuminated with an intense otherworldly violet glow emanating from within. The chitinous layer appears to be somewhat less thick in this area, however it slopes toward a pool of the violet fluid that is the source of the illumination. In a large web above the pool, a spider-like creature glances up at you from its weaving, tilts its head to the side, and chitters its mandibles at you before resuming its work above the pool.

The {@b spawn of Sryytyl} in this room is merely constructing a web and adding a layer of chitin to contain the lifeblood pool in this room. It is not aggressive unless either attacked or the chitin, web, or lifeblood is in some way harmed, in which case read or paraphrase the following:

The creature appears to grow agitated - it appears your action has been perceived as aggressive, and its mandibles unleash a series of clicks, screeches, and chitterlings before it climbs to the ceiling above and drops down just before you, sharpened limbs raised in threat. Roll for initiative!

The spawn will call for aid in the form of three more spawn and an evolved spawn, which approach from the tunnel leading to areas 4 and 5. They will retreat before all are slain, either through one of the two hallways or via another tunnel leading to area 6.
The pool of lifeblood can be described as follows:

The pool before you contains an opaque violet fluid that smells of decay, but also somewhat sweet and with a hint of metal. The fluid occasionally shudders with a faint current, but it appears a bit more stagnant than other areas. Within the fluid, a gruesome assortment of partially digested bones has collected here, and the occasional skull, scoured clean of flesh, grimaces up at you. The occasional sword or axe blade, pitted and discolored, lies at the bottom of the pool.

This mutagenic lifeblood pool is stagnant and therefore highly concentrated, as it serves as an area to degrade less digestible materials - any creature entering the pool is subjected to a {@i chronic mutagen effect}. See the Mutagen Random Tables on page 47.

A pile of rubble and rusted metal is also found in this room - materials that are not able to be digested by the lifeblood. A character can make an Investigation check, but there is nothing of value within.
The mutagen causes all kinds of horrendous afflictions.  〄

entries.name: 4. Lifeblood Geyser
entries: A small room with a statue in the center. If the characters investigate, read or paraphrase the following:

The webbing is much thicker in this room, and a number of smaller creatures are slowly moving about in the webs. They appear to be clustered around an unusual structure that suddenly erupts a spray of fluid that mists and falls below.

Every 3 rounds the lifeblood geyser will emit a burst of mutagenic fluid. The four {@b broodlings} within are huddled around the geyser as they mature, and are not aggressive unless attacked. If attacked, an additional {@b broodling swarm} that is hiding in the room will join, but several of the broodlings will also escape via tunnels if they are overwhelmed.

A creature within 10 feet of the geyser when it erupts will be exposed to an acute mutagen effect. Any creature of Sryytyl's brood within will regain 10 hit points at the start of its next turn after an eruption.

entries.name: 5. Cocoons
entries: A half dozen cocooned humanoids are found in a small nook with countless intertwined webs. As you approach, one of them shudders and you can hear a faint whisper. In response, another trembles and you can hear a faint giggle from whomever is inside.

{@b Perkas} and {@b Belda Greenbough} are hiding from the brood inside their illusory cocoons in this room, along with four deceased humans in various stages of decomposition. While suspicious at first, Perkas will remove the illusion when other, non-mutated humanoids approach. They will engage with adventurers, and willingly provide the following information:

items: They arrived recently to this floor with a rather stuffy and annoying wizard. They don't know where he is, but decided they were better off without the rambling fool.
They have managed to avoid being attacked by not being aggressive with the denizens of this floor, who seem to be observing visitors before attacking.
The creatures may have their own language, as they appear to communicate with one another.
There are several very creepy looking humanoids on this floor that appear to be mutating.

entries: On a successful {@b {@dc 15} Charisma (Persuasion)} check Perkas and Belda will reveal they have partially explored a series of small tunnels they are barely able to fit into, but that appear to be used as shortcuts to various rooms by the brood. A Small or Tiny creature, as well as the {@b broodlings, broodling swarm, spawn of Sryytyl,} and {@b evolved spawn} can navigate - through Medium or larger humanoids cannot fit within. They may also reluctantly reveal the presence of "the big one", Sryytyl, which causes the duo to shudder in revulsion.

entries.name: 6. Slumbering Giant
entries: A web-saturated hallway leads to Areas 6 and 8. Any creature attempting to traverse the area must make a successful {@b {@dc 15} Strength} check for every 10 feet moved. If they fail their check, the creature becomes restrained, and creatures risk an ambush (described below). The webbing has 20 hit points per 5 feet of webbing (AC 10), and is immune to bludgeoning and piercing damage. A creature that fails its attack roll becomes restrained by the web. The web itself is vulnerable to fire damage, but due to the density of the web in this spot, if it takes 1 point of fire damage, it erupts in a conflagration that deals 6d6 fire damage to creatures within the web (no saving throw), or 4d6 fire damage to creatures within 10 feet of the web (half damage on a successful Dexterity saving throw).

If two humanoid creatures become restrained, an adventuring party is ambushed from areas 6 (two {@b mutated humanoids}), 5 (a {@b broodling swarm}), and 3 (a {@b spawn of Sryytyl} and an {@b evolved spawn}). Several singular {@b broodlings} may also attack as needed.
The brood will attempt to prevent any creatures other than the brood from accessing this room, unless they are overwhelmed with force, in which case the brood may retreat and regroup.
Once the adventuring party enters this room, read or paraphrase the following:

You emerge from the hopeless tangle of thick webs into a large room littered with web strung across the ceiling. A large lake of the violet fluid bubbles nearby, gentle eddies and ripples flowing gently across its surface as though the lake were alive.

A huge cocoon is suspended 10 feet in the air by the impressively strong webbing. As you gaze about, warily looking for more of the vile creatures that seem to be found in every nook and cranny of this floor, the suspended creature takes a massive, shuddering breath before once again falling silent and still.

Another small cocoon contains Lorelai, one of the infested humans that is slowly being digested and added to the lifeblood. The suspended figure is an unnamed, comatose {@b hill giant} that has been subdued and poisoned into submission by Sryytyl. The magic of Karthax's imprisonment has rendered the giant immortal, and despite the constant drain and digestion of its being, Karthax's magic allows it to regenerate at a rate that has been carefully balanced by the brood.
Should any creature attempt to cut down the giant or deal damage to it (120 hit points, AC 11), read the following:

Your actions are immediately met with a series of urgent, painfully high-pitched screeches from throughout this room. Creatures hidden beneath the chitin and from within the pool burst forth, their mandibles clicking with anger. They are met with an even louder, but deeper and more urgent call that echoes off the walls and fills you with a sudden dread. Something has been terribly angered...

If the characters withdraw and make non-aggressive movements, the brood will allow them to do so as they tend to the giant. From the pool, two {@b broodling swarms} and five {@b broodlings} emerge; from random places three {@b spawn of Sryytyl} and two {@b evolved spawn} will burst forth from the chitin. After 3 rounds, Sryytyl herself will come from area 9 to drive off the intruders.

Any of Sryytyl's brood that immerses itself in the lifeblood pool in this room regenerates 10 hit points at the end of its turn as long as it has 1 hit point. If the giant is reduced to 0 hit points, the brood will gently lower it and immerse it in the lifeblood pool to aid in its regeneration. If the giant is reduced to 0 hit points, the chitin and lifeblood begin to wilt within minutes, and saving throws against either acute or chronic mutagen effects are made with advantage.

entries.name: Sryytyl's Tunnels
entries: There are large, dark tunnels in areas 6, 9, and 13 that serve similar functions to the smaller, hidden tunnels used by the brood. These allow Srrytyl and the brood to rapidly move about the floor, taking 1 turn to move to any of these areas. For creatures not of the brood, these tunnels are treated as the hallway between areas 5 and 6.

entries.name: 7. Nursery

entries: Thick webbing is found in a small, warm alcove. One humanoid figure stirs slowly within a cocoon. Numerous egg sacs are found within; immature young observed twitching at the presence of any light that illuminates them.

This area contains the last trapped human, Jashul. The egg sacs are regarded as disposable by Sryytyl - clearly they weren't strong enough to survive - though if they are destroyed the brood may lie in ambush in area 6 for the party to emerge.

If a character makes a successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation) or Wisdom (Perception)} check while searching among the egg sacs, they will discover a pitted and well worn mace covered in lifeblood, webbing, and chitin:
{@item Genetic Changer|gp_karthax}

entries.name: 8. Alyryne's Hideout

entries: The webbing in this room appears to be different somehow - deliberately constructed to mimic the natural webbing in this area, but somehow less organic. A small, brightly lit pool of the violet liquid has been deliberately kept open, though the chitin surrounding it appears to be attempting to repair itself. A crudely constructed altar of bones is being tended to by a humanoid wearing rags that moves quite unnaturally. As the being senses your presence, her head jerks up, and you immediately recoil at the horror before you.

Alyryne Do'Lyl has made this area into a shrine where she worships the brood - perhaps the only reason she is still alive is due to the odd behavior that Sryytyl has never before seen and feels the need to study. Alyryne will not attack unless to defend herself or the shrine she has constructed, rightly believing it is the only reason she is permitted to survive. She will reluctantly reveal a bit about her past, however a {@b {@dc 13} Charisma (Intimidation or Persuasion)} check is required for her to reveal the following:

items: She believes the brood mother in this floor is one of the eld gods worshiped by her ancestors.
The brood mother has spoken to her and revealed her name - Sryytyl the Devourer.
Alyryne believes Sryytyl will once again be unleashed upon the world and bring with her an age of enlightenment and ascension to the next state of existence.

entries: With a roll of 16 or more on a Charisma (Intimidation) check, Alyryne will also reveal:

items: Any humanoid that survives more than a few days without being killed by the brood quickly mutates into a {@b mutated humanoid}.
The brood has both a series of hidden tunnels they use to move about from the various rooms as well as a larger tunnel system Sryytyl uses.

entries.name: 9. Altar of Karthax

entries: An elongated room perhaps 60 feet long and 20 feet wide appears to have once been a place of worship before the infestation took over. A large, dark tunnel has been bored into the middle of this room. Peering inside cautiously you see a hopelessly complex tangle of webbing and the air within is both stagnant and putrid. At the far end of the room lies what appears to be a raised altar, suspiciously free of the chitinous growth ubiquitous on this floor. A faint light beckons you toward it.

The altar is a remnant of the construction of The Living Tower by Karthax. A {@b {@dc 17} Intelligence (History)} check will indicate it is at least as old as the tower itself. The altar is inscribed in runes of a similar language to those observed on the teleportation glyphs, but their meaning is lost to time.

A character under the influence of a {@i comprehend languages} spell or similar is able to read the runes, which supposedly allow a worshiper to commune with Karthax as per the {@i commune} spell. If a creature spends 1 minute chanting and invoking the ritual, the faint light emanating from the altar brightens and the character is able to ask Karthax three yes/no questions. After the questions have been asked, the altar light fades away completely, and each creature within 20 feet of the altar regains 2d8 + 7 hit points and is under the effect of the {@i bless} spell.

entries.name: 10. Worn Depression

entries: The chitin in this room has a large depression within it, as though some large creature was nesting or resting here. A shriveled cocoon is suspended nearby.
This room is where Sryytyl frequently settles to rest, and has recently consumed a wrapped humanoid. Otherwise, there is nothing of interest in the room.

entries.name: 11. Seldezar's Stand

entries: Approaching a hallway that branches off the main path, you hear muttering and cursing in the Common tongue. Peering around the corner you see a tall, cloaked figure surrounded by the corpses of several of the insect-like creatures that have their carapaces pitted and scorched as though by acid. The creatures are lying on their backs, legs curled toward the ceiling and twitching like a spider would curl. Several have had their carapaces peeled back methodically to reveal their internal anatomy.
Sensing your presence, the human turns to you, dark eyes flashing with irritation:  "{@i well, about time someone showed up.}"

Seldezar D'Lael has just disposed of several {@b broodlings} and has been conducting crude autopsies to understand the creatures within. He suspects they are mutated spider progeny, but will prefer to keep that information to himself. Seldezar will engage dismissively with Perkas and Belda if they are present, who in turn will do everything in their power to annoy the wizard. If Alyryne Do'Lyl is present, he will be initially quite disgusted before giving way to morbid curiosity, and may even attempt to conduct some experiments on her as well.

Seldezar will have hypothesized that the violet mutagenic lifeblood is the source of mutation, and thus will use any opportunity to test this - carefully studying a character exposed to it, for example, or spending extra time examining a slain {@b mutated humanoid}. He may even attempt to coerce exposure or trick another creature into willingly exposing themselves to the mutagen if he sees the opportunity to do so.

entries.name: 12. Mutated Humanoid Gathering

entries: A narrow tunnel, clearly carved out of the tower's stone as opposed to constructed, winds into a 30-foot wide room. The stench of decay threatens to overwhelm your nose. Peering inside the room you see the glitter of several sets of malicious eyes. The creatures turn to you, revealing a horrific set of random insect-like features mixed with what were once humanoid - but their insect-like eyes are now completely devoid of any recognition of hope.
The room is inhabited by four {@b mutated humanoids} who will attack any who enter this room.

entries.name: 13. Sryytyl's Bolt Hole

entries: A shallow depression leads to a large, dark tunnel that is overcome with webs. A stench of rot, must, and decay greets you as you approach.
This room serves as a potential lair for Sryytyl, as it is connected to the tunnels Areas 6 and 9.

entries.name: Sryytyl's Behavior and Tactics
entries: Sryytyl is well aware that, despite her immortality and unlike the giant within the floor she keeps in a comatose state, she is nonetheless vulnerable without her brood. If her brood has been eradicated she may use these tunnels to separate and isolate individual creatures, spawn additional broodlings, and regenerate in the lifeblood pool as well as protect the comatose giant in area 6. She may well choose to lead the adventurers on a wild chase throughout the floor, choosing engagements and setting broodling ambushes.

entries.name: Completing this Floor
entries: The floor infested by Srrytyl the Devourer is completed upon the defeat of Sryytyl. Once this condition is met, one of two situations may occur. If the party has aided Seldezar D'Lael in subduing the creature, read or paraphrase the following:

You can sense the palpable relief emanating from the very walls of the tower as the monstrous spider's legs curl and twitch in the throes of death. A tingling sensation begins to creep over you, starting with your legs and rapidly ascending. As the sensation reaches your belly, you quickly become queasy and within moments vomit upon the chitinous floor. The teleportation glyphs begin to whirl before your eyes, but just before you lose consciousness, you hear a voice crack out boldly:
"{@i Not yet! I must understand what has happened here! I will bind myself to your service until I have discovered this creature's secrets!}"

The tingling subsides and the crackle of magic lessens for but a moment. Turning your eyes back to the remains of the massive spider, you see the cloaked figure of Seldezar crouch down, muttering to himself once again. The magic surrounding you intensifies, and your last thought is wondering exactly what fate the arrogant wizard has bound himself to - and what the cost might be.

Seldezar's fate would remain a mystery at this point, but ponder what potential villainy a necromancer who understands how to rapidly manipulate a living creature's very physical makeup could cause...what undead creatures could such a wizard create, and what havoc could be brought upon the living once Seldezar's service to Karthax is complete?
Alternatively, if Seldezar is slain by either the brood or the party, read the following:

You can sense the palpable relief emanating from the very walls of the tower as the monstrous spider's legs curl and twitch in the throes of death. A tingling sensation begins to creep over you, starting with your legs and rapidly ascending. As the sensation reaches your belly, you quickly become queasy and within moments vomit upon the chitinous floor. The chitin looks shriveled and limp, and the violet glow from within has begun to subside. The teleportation glyphs begin to whirl before your eyes, and you rapidly lose consciousness.
Oddly enough you don't mind, knowing this is the end of your time on this foul floor.

entries.name: Acute Mutagen Exposure
entries: When a creature is exposed to the mutagen on Sryytyl's floor for an acute period of time (for example, if a creature breaks through the chitin layer on the floor of Sryytyl's lair or fails their saving throw when exposed to Sryytyl's bite or mutagen spray legendary ability, roll a d12. After 5 turns, the creature is subjected to the described effect until it completes a short or long rest. The effect has a 10% chance of lasting 1d4 days. An acute effect may be removed by a {@i lesser restoration} spell.

entries.caption: Acute Mutagen Exposure Effects
rows: {@i You feel groggy and disoriented. Your vision becomes blurry, and others look at your eyes with shock.} The character's pupils have begun to turn jet-black and look like those of an insect. The character has blindsight to 30 ft., but has disadvantage on ability checks that rely on sight.

{@i You can almost begin to feel slight tremors in the air, and noises seem abnormally loud.} The character has no noticeable physiological change. The character can use the {@b Web Sense} ability possessed by Sryytyl's brood, but has disadvantage on ability checks that rely on hearing and is vulnerable to thunder damage.
{@i Your senses begin to seem much keener, as though your perception has sharpened somehow.} The character has no noticeable physiological change, but has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.

{@i You feel a bit weak, slow, and generally groggy, as though sick.} Other characters notice a sickly green tinge to the affected character's skin tone. The character has disadvantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws.

{@i Your tongue begins to swell to an abnormally large size, constricting your mouth, making it very difficult to speak.} The character's face, throat, and mouth are significantly swollen. The character is unable to speak and cannot cast spells requiring verbal components.

{@i You feel violently ill very quickly, and spontaneously vomit the contents of your stomach upon the floor. You begin to feel incredibly.....warm.} Exposed skin of the affected character has broken out into pustules. The character makes all Charisma ability checks with disadvantage, and if it fails any saving throw by 5 or more, they spend their next action retching and vomiting.

{@i You feel oddly...good, despite being exposed to that nauseating fluid. Somehow you feel a bit...stronger.} The character has no noticeable physiological change, but has advantage on Constitution saving throws.

{@i You feel absolutely wretched after being exposed to the violet liquid that seems pervasive in this area. But for some reason you can hear and even....understand....the faint chittering of the loathsome creatures infesting this floor.} The character appears sickly to others, and has disadvantage on Charisma ability checks, but can interpret the language of the brood that resides on this floor.
{@i Covered in that disgusting violet fluid seems to have no effect on you.} No effect occurs to the exposed character.

{@i Revolting.....you took a spray of purple goo right in your eyes. Now everything seems blurry.} The character's eyes have become filmed over with a hazy film. They make attack rolls and any ability checks or saving throws that rely on sight with disadvantage.

{@i Revolting.....you took a spray of purple goo right in your eyes. Now everything seems to have a very odd glow about it.} The character's eyes have turned purple. They gain darkvision to a range of 120 ft., and the character can see the presence of magic within 30 feet of it. If the creature senses magic in this way, it can use an action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and the creature can learn its school of magic if it had the ability to cast spells prior to this effect. This ability can penetrate most barriers, but is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.

{@i Everything seems disorienting. You can hear random murmurs in your head, which grow louder and louder. You begin to feel very confused, uncertain...very unlike your normal self...}  The character has no noticeable physiological change, but acts as though under the influence of the {@i confusion} spell.

entries.name: Chronic Mutagen Exposure
entries: If a creature completes a Short Rest while in Sryytyl's lair, it has a 25% chance of being subjected to a chronic mutagen effect (a roll of 1 on a d4). Roll a d12; the creature is subjected to the described effect, which lasts 1d4 days after leaving the presence of the mutagen before returning to a normal state. As an optional rule, this effect has a 10% chance of becoming permanent (a roll of 10 on a d10).

A {@i lesser restoration} spell has a 50% chance of reversing these effects before they become permanent. These effects are cumulative, that is a character can be affected by more than one acute or chronic exposure effect. If the character spends more than 3 long rests exposed to the mutagen, its chronic effects have a 50% chance of becoming permanent, and after 1 week of exposure they are permanently transformed by the mutagen into a {@b mutated humanoid} and cannot be restored to their former selves short of a {@i wish}.

entries.caption: Chronic Mutagen Exposure Effects
rows: {@i You awaken from your long rest, but something feels very, very wrong. Your body feels very heavy for some reason, and your skin is discolored and hardened.} The character's skin has begun to change to a chitinous exoskeleton. The character's AC increases by 1, but its Charisma ability score decreases by 2.

{@i You awaken from your slumber feeling unusually well-rested and energetic. But for some reason when you look at your arm, the veins are noticeably a different color.} Mutagen has spread throughout the creature's bloodstream. Each time the character takes slashing or piercing damage, any creature within a 5-foot radius of them must make a {@b {@dc 13} Dexterity}saving throw or have a 25% chance of being exposed to an acute mutagen effect. The character regenerates 1 hit point at the start of its turn, and their Constitution ability score increases by 1.

{@i You practically jump up from your rest, feeling nimble and light on your feet for some reason.} There are no noticeable physiological changes to the character, but their Dexterity ability score increases by 1.

{@i Your eyelids feel unusually heavy as you open them, and your vision is very unusual when you do so - as though you are peering at the world through countless glasses filled with water.} The character's eyes have begun to resemble those of an insect. The character gains darkvision to a distance of 60 ft. but their Charisma ability score is reduced by 1.

{@i For some reason you awaken feeling bright and sharp, almost as though simply being in this wretched place has granted you some new insight into life.} There are no noticeable effects on the character, however the gain they ability to innately cast one of the following random spells once per day: {@i acid splash, light, mending, minor illusion, poison spray, prestidigitation, produce flame, resistance.}

{@i You awaken, nothing unusual appears to have happened to you during your rest.} The character experiences no noticeable physiological effect, but is immune to the mutagen's effects for the next 24 hours.

{@i You awaken feeling lighter and more agile than when you lay down to rest. Looking at your limbs you notice they have begun to shrink and are beginning to sprout long, coarse, dark hair.} The mutagen has begun to change the structure of the character's limbs into a spider-like state. The character's Strength ability score is decreased by 1, but their Dexterity ability score is increased by 1, and they have advantage on Dexterity (Acrobatics) ability checks made to climb.

{@i You awaken and feel sickly....groggy, nauseous, and unusually weak compared to when you laid down to rest.} The character is noticeably pale, and is not responding well to the mutagen's effects. Their Constitution ability score is reduced by 1, and they only regain half their normal hit die during a long rest.

{@i Nothing seems amiss as you open your eyes. Not sure what everyone is complaining about.....} there are no physiological effects, but the character becomes resistant to poison damage and makes saving throws against being poisoned with advantage.

{@i As you begin to stir, the first thing you hear is your companions complain of your unusually loud snoring. As you turn to speak with them, the sight of you causes them to recoil in horror.} The character's mouth has begun to change into a set of mandibles similar to those of one of Sryytyl's brood. The character gains the ability to bite (Melee Weapon Attack, 3 (1d6) piercing damage plus 5 (2d4) poison damage) but their Charisma ability score is reduced by 2. The character's speech is accentuated with the clicks of the growing mandibles.

{@i You feel energetic and unusually attuned to your surroundings, as though your senses have somehow been heightened.} The mutagen has subtly improved the character's senses, despite no observable effect. The character gains proficiency with the Wisdom (Perception) ability check, if they weren't already proficient in this skill.

{@i You awaken from your rest as you normally would, but your arms feel heavier than normal. When you roll up your sleeves (or vambraces), you are alarmed at large, unusual growths on either forearm. You quickly jolt at the foreign growths on your arms, but as you do so, a spray of webbing painfully erupts from one of the growths and shoots across the room, impacting on the opposite wall.} The character gains the ability to use the {@b Web} action possessed by Sryytyl's brood, but each time they do they take 3 (1d6) piercing damage and their Charisma ability score reduces by 1 (minimum 3).

entries.name: Background
entries: Archaeological records suggest that civilizations have risen and fallen several times over the course of many millennia. While artifacts from long past eras are nearly impossible to find, some have been discovered in a remote desert.

Those few structures that have been revealed by the sands and then explored are filled with clever traps and ancient devices, hidden doors, and false ceilings designed to protect the remains of the ancient beings entombed within. To add to these dangers, magical illusions and curses are often layered upon each other in the central rooms of these tombs. Several recently discovered tombs contain brilliantly colored murals depicting ancient life, as well as creatures thought to exist only in the dreams and fantasies of mortals.

The civilization thought to be responsible for the construction of these structures appears to have thrived for centuries before suddenly disappearing for reasons unknown, leading to an age of darkness before the arrival of the Eld Gods.

These beings placed great stock in the importance of life after death. Centuries of experimentation with magics now viewed as evil or forbidden were conducted in an effort to reveal the secrets of death. Priests and priestesses were thus of great importance, having the power to guide souls into the afterlife. The dead were entombed in grand tombs along with immeasurable wealth to ensure favorable passage of the soul to its next journey.

Nephetes-em-Xhakar was once a high priestess  who, after countless failed rituals and ceremonies, finally uncovered the secret to immortality. She was able to separate her soul from her body, which was then magically sealed in an ornate vessel and hidden away in a secret location. Her body was preserved by the skilled practitioners of mummification and thus endured the ravages of time. Nephetes-em-Xhakar became known as the Deathless Lady.

Fearing her power but also knowing Nephetes-em-Xhakar could never be truly slain so long as the vessel containing her soul remained intact, a secret group of nobles abducted the Deathless Lady, spirited her away far to the North in a remote land, and sealed her body within a remote tomb that was constructed beneath a dormant fire mountain.

When the magics summoned by the Eld Gods during the Great Cataclysm caused the fire mountain containing the Deathless Lady's tomb to erupt, she awoke from her millennia-long slumber within her tomb. At the height of the Great Cataclysm, when Karthax constructed The Living Tower, the stone of her tomb was woven into its foundation and Karthax offered a bargain: the location of the vessel containing the Deathless Lady's soul if she but stayed for a while longer within The Living Tower.
Immortality is an illusion. Even a deity must pass through the shrouded veil of death. 〄

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: We have envisioned the Deathless Lady as a lich of great power and greed from an era that precedes even that of the Great Cataclysm. Her tomb is similar  to that which has been found in ancient Egypt, with brightly colored murals, elaborate traps, and hidden doorways. To add to this, several magical spells and undead guardians are also found within this floor, which has not been visited in some time.

Undead are often portrayed as mindless evil killing machines, or at the very least frequently evil. However, not all undead creatures are evil, and for those with their own free will, their motivations may vary. Evil and Good are after all concepts that are relative to one's point of view. Talqal and Sethnal, the supposed loyal seneschals of the Deathless Lady, are in fact guardians to ensure Nephetes-em-Xhakar remains entombed for all time — and will attempt to deflect, deceive, and lure adventurers away from the inner sanctum of this floor. They may even attempt to lure visitors into the traps built into this floor, magical and physical — but doing so in subtle ways to avoid suspicion.

Also found on this floor is Raquel Saqat, a holy warrior whose bloodline is thought to have perhaps descended from the Eld Gods themselves. This powerful warrior seeks not necessarily justice, but certainly vengeance for perceived wrongs in the world.
As the adventurers delve deeper into this floor, consider the following:

items: The remains of countless visitors to this floor, victims of the traps within (that are periodically reset by Talqal and Sethnal) have reanimated and are now mindless undead threats in addition to the traps within this floor.

Consider the motivations of the seneschals. While they will outwardly attempt to aid the adventurers (and may even support them in defeating the mindless undead in this floor), they are cunning, deceptive, and will reveal only enough to seem truthful while luring adventurers to their death.
The {@b Inmortui Enchiridion} in the Disciple's Table room (Area 12) was penned by the Deathless Lady some many years ago, prior to her transformation.

The Deathless Lady, while weakened by time and distance from her soul, remains formidable. She will not necessarily attack, but may implore Karthax to release the visitors from her floor should one of them swear fealty to her and undergo a ritual to become undead. Her motivation is not to kill indiscriminately, but rather to spread what she perceives as the power of immortality to all who would have it — thus she requires a representative to the outside world willing to spread her word.

Raquel Saqat has also found his way to the tomb of the Deathless Lady. As a paladin, he is uneasy about the undead, and is mistrustful of their intentions — a potential interaction with the Deathless Lady may cause an eruption of violence.

entries.name: Nephetes, the Deathless Lady
entries: Nephetes-em-Xhakar comes from humble beginnings, though she can scarcely remember them herself aside from fleeting memories. Her father was a stonemason; her mother worked as a servant to one of the many lesser nobles of the time. They lived upon the banks of a great river that provided water used to irrigate fields of grain and was home to countless species of fish. During times of flooding, the great river would deposit rich silt and nutrient-laden soil from upriver that nourished the many people of this civilization.

While education was reserved only for the very wealthy, a local priestess took note of Nephetes' interest in the teachings of the gods, depicted amidst the countless temples devoted to the pantheon. This priestess took the young girl under her wing, teaching her about the ways of the gods as well as the thousands of rituals to honor them. As both her voracious and curious mind grew, Nephetes was exposed to more secretive rituals and incantations. Her keen mind absorbed all she was exposed to, and within a few years Nephetes was able to perfectly recite each sermon and ceremony devoted to each member of the pantheon, even the lesser deities.

Her knowledge was highly sought after, and Nephetes — taking the honorific em-Xhakar once she had been brought into the upper echelons of the priesthood — was soon sought after by nobles who would implore her to present their wishes, plights, and deepest desires to the gods on their behalf. Many of these nobles, their coffers awash with wealth, wanted for nothing, but feared for their immortal souls. Indeed, this civilization had become obsessed with wealth as well as the fate of their souls.

Seeing the worries of nobles and the commoner alike, Nephetes-em-Xhakar began to search for answers within the teachings of the gods — she began a quest to uncover the secret to immortality. Long had this civilization practiced mummification and other means of preserving the body, as well as constructing monuments to protect both body and soul once they had been parted by age, disease, or war; however, none had perfected the means to preserve the link between body and soul even if separated.

Knowing the link between body and soul was crucial to maintaining life after death, Nephetes-em-Xhakar experimented with countless rituals and incantations. She found eager volunteers for her experimental incantations and spells, such was her reputation among the people that they were willing to risk their bodies and souls for even the chance at immortality. Nephetes-em-Xhakar thus tested her necromantic spells on thousands of willing victims who offered themselves as sacrifices in rituals devoted to blood gods, night gods, moon gods, gods of the earth — any who might bestow a deathless life upon a willing soul.

Deeper she delved into ever darker necromantic teachings. Eventually, with an occult and twisted ceremony devoted to one of the least known deities, Nephetes-em-Xhakar was able to separate a soul — her own — from her body by sacrificing the willing life-essence of her followers, and was able to store her soul within an ornate canopic jar that was magically rendered nigh indestructible. Her body was mummified to preserve it, however, and would resemble that of an ancient, wizened crone  forever more. The secrets of undeath had been unleashed upon the world.

Over the next century or so, Nephetes-em-Xhakar was worshiped as a demigoddess by her people. She guarded her incantations and rituals jealousy, and amassed a following and wealth that rivaled even the most powerful of the rulers of the time, whom she ritualistically slew and raised again as legions of immortal undead to serve her every whim. The descendants of these undead exist to this day, the undead trait passed on through necromantic incantation or cursed bite alike.

However, with power came suspicion and paranoia. Fearing for her soul contained within a canopic jar, Nephetes-em-Xhakar entrusted it to one of her most loyal servants who hid it deep within a tomb of some long deceased noble among others just like it. No one but that one loyal servant knew of its location, and after it was hidden, they were slain — preserving Nephetes-em-Xhakar's soul forever.

Her paranoia proved correct. Nephetes-em-Xhakar's body was subdued by a jealous cohort of nobles who feared her power over the undead, entombed, and spirited away far to the North. There, a tomb was constructed beneath a great dormant volcano and hidden deep within the stone. Traps of all kinds, magical and mundane, as well as illusions, enchantments, and any number of incantations were cast to prevent the tomb's discovery and penetration by would-be tomb raiders. Several of her servants were also entombed within to watch over the  Deathless Lady, to ensure she would not ever be set free.

The tomb remained silent, sealed, for millennia until Karthax raised The Living Tower out of the blasted wastelands decimated by the resurrecting of the extinct firemountain.  The Deathless Lady had by then awoken, and as The Living Tower was being constructed, sensed freedom was within her grasp. However, time and distance from her soul, sealed in a location unknown even to her, had stripped her of much of her power. Thus, while Karthax was raising The Living Tower, the Deathless Lady made a deal with the Eld God: the location of the canopic jar containing her soul in exchange for but a few centuries more. For what is time to the immortal undead?
So many of the mortal races yearn to live forever. Undeath but stays death's hand — it simply makes oneself a target... 〄

{@b Roleplaying Nephetes-em-Xhakar.} The Deathless Lady is physically weakened in her current state within The Living Tower and her mind has been clouded by time. However, she retains a potent understanding of magic. She is not a direct threat unless provoked, as she would rather seek loyalty in a potential follower as opposed to instilling fear.
She can be voiced as follows:

items: When first awakening from her slumber:  "{@i I awaken once more...it has been...some time...who would seek my counsel?}"
When interacting with the servants within this floor, Talqal and Sethnal:  "{@i My loyal servants...bring me my robes. I thank you for your service.}"
The Deathless Lady will offer to bestow immortality (undeath) upon any who voice interest in doing so:  "{@i I see the desire within you...you crave immortality...do you not?}"

entries: Nephetes-em-Xhakar was present when Karthax constructed The Living Tower, and thus has a great deal of knowledge about it. She will reveal the following, but must recall such information. Adventurers must succeed on a {@b {@dc 15} Charisma (Persuasion)} check for her to attempt to recall information about The Living Tower, which then depends on the Deathless Lady making an Intelligence (History) check (reveal each bit of information preceding the History check if successful as well):

items: Roll of 10 or less:  "{@i I...cannot recall...there was a voice...a strange being...stone...then sleep once more.}"
Roll of 11:  "{@i I was there when the tower was constructed...I recall the being was of shadow, their face shrouded. We spoke at length, but I cannot recall more.}"
Roll of 12:  "{@i Karthax was the name...I recall them being quite persuasive.}"
Roll of 13:  "{@i Karthax said they raised the tower to ensure freedom, and that I was his first guest.}"
Roll of 14:  "{@i The tower was constructed out of the remains of a firemountain. I must have been brought here by the jealous traitors who feared my power!}"
Roll of 15:  "{@i Karthax said there would be visitors at times, and that they would need to be tested. If worthy, he would offer them a place within the tower.}"
Roll of 16:  "{@i Karthax was furious — a demon had struck at one of their kind, turning the tides of some great battle. The tower was to ensure his inevitable victory.}"
Roll of 17:  "{@i Some previous visitors to my tomb have thought of Karthax as some sort of god. But I know gods, and they are not one of them.}"
Roll of 18:  "{@i We discussed and debated which was more powerful, choice or imposition. We agree on much — it is better for followers to do so of their own volition as opposed to being forced.}"
Roll of 19:  "{@i I recall now...I was betrayed! It must have been...you!!!}" (Nephetes-em-Xhakar will then attack Talqal and Sethnal).
Roll of 20: Nephetes-em-Xhakar will recall all of the above, and tell the adventurers of her history as depicted above.

entries.name: Raquel Saqat
entries: Raquel Saqat is a holy warrior whose bloodline bears the origins of the Eld Gods, be it through procreation or simply being one of the chosen imbued with magical powers from these beings. Bearing the signs of being touched by the Eld Gods — feathered wings erupting from between his shoulders — Raquel's family chose a simple life in a remote village far from where their origins would be scrutinized. Hiding their true nature, Raquel's parents were strict and disciplined, their loyalty directed to a lesser noble who tolerated no disloyalty and commanded absolute obedience from his subjects.

The young Raquel was initiated into a warrior order at a relatively young age, and distinguished himself well as a loyal servant to his lord. Raquel became a paladin of some renown, known for bringing the firm, steel fist of justice wherever the innocent were wronged. All was well until a minor conflict with a neighboring noble escalated. Raquel and his soldiers were dispatched to resolve the conflict, but came across a massacre of villagers under his lord's protection. Furious, the warrior sought his lord's permission to bring the perpetrators to justice.

The unthinkable occurred: his lord, whom Raquel revered and obeyed unerringly, forbade the paladin from pursuing the murderers, for it was an effort to goad Raquel's house into a conflict with a vastly superior force. Raquel was forbidden from bringing those responsible to justice — for political reasons he could not understand.

Torn between loyalty and his sense of right, the paladin chose justice — though some might call it vengeance — and abandoned his lord. Alone, the conflicted paladin unleashed his fury in the black of night upon a force he thought responsible for the massacre. His actions triggered a war that would lead to the deaths of the soldiers who once followed him, as well as the lord whom he once admired so deeply.

Outcast and disgraced, the paladin pursued a new path — to pursue not only justice, but vengeance — for to him, every life matters, and is deserving of both. In his view, both justice and vengeance are two sides to the same coin. Spreading his wings and embracing his true lineage and the powers bestowed upon him with it, the paladin, perhaps descended from the Eld Gods themselves, traveled for many years on personal vendetta. Eventually, the hinterlands and the savage, lawlessness beckoned. The paladin was pursuing a band of bandits at the edge of the wasteland containing The Living Tower when he became ensnared in its magic.

Entering The Living Tower, he debated with Karthax for some time, arguing justice, law, and order are the only truths that matter, concepts the Eld God bemusedly discussed with the warrior. Sensing the paladin's bloodline and gifts, Karthax offered Raquel what he desired most — the power to avenge the innocent fallen — if he would but pit his wits and steel against that of his guests.

{@b Roleplaying Raquel Saqat.} Raquel Saqat is bound by two binding principles: that each and every life matters, and that he must do (what he perceives to be) the greatest good, at any cost. The paladin may be found in clad shining steel armor, specially crafted to allow his feathered wings to spread from between his shoulders — other times with no breastplate at all. He is rigid in his views of right and wrong. If interacting with characters of lawful or good alignment he will often be agreeable and a powerful ally; chaotic- or evil-aligned characters are often goaded and taunted, perhaps even engaged outright if sufficiently provoked. Raquel can be articulated as follows:

items: When describing how he came to The Living Tower:  "{@i I pursued a band of raiders into the wastelands, became disoriented, and somehow found myself at the tower. That arrogant, snide presence had the audacity to challenge me to enter and pit my mettle against his &#quot;guests&#quot; — and here I am in this dusty tomb.}"
When describing his past:  "{@i I have but one goal: justice for those deserving of it and vengeance for the fallen innocent.}"

When questioned about his wings:  "{@i As a child, my parents and I would have to hide our true nature. Touched by the Eld Gods, or so they said. Now I would spread my wings and strike fear into the lawless.}"

When interacting with undead, such as Talqal, Sethnal, or the Deathless Lady, Raquel will be suspicious, taunting, sarcastic, and disrespectful — attempting to goad them into an argument or even combat.

entries.name: Wizen: Sethnal and Talqal
entries: Sethnal and Talqal were once two of Nephetes-em-Xhakar's most loyal followers. Both were part of her entourage, and were privy to many of her secrets, being among her most fervent supporters who, once the Deathless Lady had uncovered the secret to bestowing undeath upon a willing living creature, volunteered themselves to serve her evermore. They even witnessed the first ceremony in which Nephetes-em-Xhakar first separated her soul and sealed it away in a canopic jar.

However, they grew concerned with the growing ambition and power the Deathless Lady wielded. While they once viewed her as a vassal of the gods themselves, they began to perceive that the Deathless Lady's ambition and power over necromancy might eventually cause the extinction of their civilization. The duo were approached by a cabal of nobles who likewise were concerned by the potential impacts of unleashing undeath upon the world. Talqal and Sethnal thus provided critical information to the cabal — the time when the Deathless Lady's guard would change and she would be at her most vulnerable. The cabal created an elaborate ruse — abducting Nephetes-em-Xhakar, as well as her two trusted advisors, who were then entombed with her beneath the dormant firemountain ostensibly to serve as her seneschals for all time - but in reality, to ensure she would not be unleashed upon the world once more, remaining as The Deathless Lady's Wizen until the end of time.

{@b Roleplaying Sethnal and Talqal.} The seneschals of the Deathless Lady are outwardly unwaveringly loyal to Nephetes-em-Xhakar, and will take every effort to play their part. When encountering visitors to this floor, they will make every effort to divert them away from the Deathless Lady's inner sanctum and minimize any chance of her being freed (adventurers may suspect they have ulterior motives with a successful {@b {@dc 18} Charisma (Deception)} check). They are exceeding courteous to visitors, treating them with the utmost respect. However, they will feign not knowing (or forgetting) about the many physical traps within this floor, and even luring adventurers into these traps lest they awaken Nephetes-em-Xhakar. They are unaffected by any of the enchantments and curses present in this floor and can be articulated as follows:

items: When first interacting with new visitors:  "{@i Ah, welcome to thee, guests of Karthax. It has been a great many years since we last had visitors.}"
When describing this floor:  "{@i This is the resting place of our mistress, the Deathless Lady. She would welcome you, but alas, I cannot remember where she lies in rest.}"

When describing how they came to be in The Living Tower:  "{@i We were entrusted to serve our Lady for all eternity. She was entombed out of ignorance and fear of her power over death — those fearful mortals never knew what gifts she could bestow upon them. But our lady is patient and forgiving — she understands the fear they must have held, and in her wisdom would help them to see the truth of immortality and have them not fear it.}"
When asked about the floor:  "{@i I cannot quite remember...I have slumbered for so long, and I only recall a bit of how this tomb was built. I have not seen it all.}"

entries: Sethnal and Talqal were once two of Nephetes-em-Xhakar's most loyal followers. Both were part of her entourage, and were privy to many of her secrets, being among her most fervent supporters who, once the Deathless Lady had uncovered the secret to bestowing undeath upon a willing living creature, volunteered themselves to serve her evermore. They even witnessed the first ceremony in which Nephetes-em-Xhakar first separated her soul and sealed it away in a canopic jar.

However, they grew concerned with the growing ambition and power the Deathless Lady wielded. While they once viewed her as a vassal of the gods themselves, they began to perceive that the Deathless Lady's ambition and power over necromancy might eventually cause the extinction of their civilization. When encountering visitors to this floor, they will make every effort to divert them away from the Deathless Lady's inner sanctum and minimize any chance of her being freed (adventurers may suspect they have ulterior motives with a successful {@b {@dc 18} Charisma (Deception)} check). They are exceeding courteous to visitors, treating them with the utmost respect. However, they will feign not knowing (or forgetting) about the many physical traps within this floor, and even luring adventurers into these traps lest they awaken Nephetes-em-Xhakar. items: When first interacting with new visitors:  "{@i Ah, welcome to thee, guests of Karthax. It has been a great many years since we last had visitors.}"
When describing this floor:  "{@i This is the resting place of our mistress, the Deathless Lady. She would welcome you, but alas, I cannot remember where she lies in rest.}"
