When describing how they came to be in The Living Tower:  "{@i We were entrusted to serve our Lady for all eternity. She was entombed out of ignorance and fear of her power over death — those fearful mortals never knew what gifts she could bestow upon them. But our lady is patient and forgiving — she understands the fear they must have held, and in her wisdom would help them to see the truth of immortality and have them not fear it.}"
When asked about the floor:  "{@i I cannot quite remember...I have slumbered for so long, and I only recall a bit of how this tomb was built. I have not seen it all.}"

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Rune

entries: The incessant buzz of mystical energies that overwhelmed your senses has ceased, and is replaced by an eerie silence.  The nausea that accompanies your teleportation to this floor subsides quickly, and you settle for a moment to catch your bearings. You are surrounded by darkness, as though you have been submerged in black ink. It is oppressively hot and dry, and the slightest movement causes a cloud of dust to overwhelm your nose, causing you to sneeze violently.

As you take a few tentative steps forward, your eyes adjust and you can make out the faint flicker of what might be torchlight rebounding from the walls of a hallway that descends downward and bends away from you.

The rough stone has been crudely carved by mason's tools - dwarven stonecrafting will immediately identify the construction as ancient and crude by today's standards. The stone itself is igneous, and consistent with that which is found in volcanic regions. Ancient torch sconces line the walls at regular intervals, empty and with a thick layer of dust.

A single set of humanoid tracks (a successful {@b {@dc 12} Wisdom (Survival)} check indicates they are only a few hours old) follows the bending path. The path itself slopes downward at a roughly 15-degree angle. The dry air becomes even more unbearable as the adventurers follow the sloping path.

entries.name: 2. Laborer's Quarters
entries: The descending, curved path leads to a long abandoned room that once served as living quarters for the laborers who toiled to construct this ancient tomb. Once their job was completed, these laborers were slain and entombed in plain stone sarcophagi. Read or paraphrase the following:

The impact of steel on bone greets you as you enter this room. In the far corner, you see a steel-clad warrior decapitating one desiccated, rag-clad being with a mighty blow. The head rolls toward you, long wisps of hair collecting dust as it settles near your feet, its face turned upward to you. For a moment it is somewhat still, before the parchment skin covering its jaws spasms, eyeless lids blink once at you and its jaws begin gnashing as though trying to reach you.
Horrified, your gaze returns to see the warrior struggling against a second skeletal humanoid. The warrior's eyes meet yours..."
Once the two {@b deathless servants} have been dispatched by a winded {@b Raquel Saqal} (potentially with aid from the adventurers), have them engage — but with Raquel's warning:

"{@i Well met... and thank you. Be warned, some filthy magic binds these wretches to this room — even if dismembered they will rise and rise again. I have slain this pair countless times over the past few hours, and still they come.}"

Once the last of the new arrivals enters this room, the exit back to the teleportation glyph is magically sealed with an impenetrable barrier, nearly imperceptible but for a shimmering field once touched. Any creature that comes into contact with the field takes 1d4 necrotic damage and must succeed on a {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw or make attack rolls and saving throws with disadvantage for 3 rounds. Undead creatures can pass through without any effect.

The {@b deathless servants} are bound to this room by a curse that causes their bodies to reassemble every 5 minutes. They will relentlessly assault any living creatures within this room, eventually overwhelming and slaying any non-undead creatures. If the adventurers and Raquel take too long to interact, consider having them rise and assault the party.
Read or paraphrase the following description of the room once the adventurers have the opportunity to look around:

The room before you opens into a large space containing several plain, unmarked stone sarcophagi. The lids of several have been shattered, and the remaining lids, save one, are askew as though moved aside. A series of shelves and racks that once appeared to have held mason's tools, chisels, shovels, and picks have been shattered; the tools strewn about. A large pile of debris: stone, broken tools, and even several humanoid bones lay piled in the center of the room.

The lids of the stone sarcophagi are heavy, but can be moved aside with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics)} check. Aside from a layer of dust there is nothing within, except the sarcophagus in the northwest corner, which contains the remains of another mummified body ({@b Talqal}). Talqal will remain unaffected by the curse in this room, and only animate once the concealed hallway in the northeast corner of the room is opened.

The entrance to the concealed hallway is a false wall, which is nearly indistinguishable from the other stone walls in this room, having been rebuilt by Talqal each time it is breached by any who discover and destroy it. A successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation)} check indicates slight differences in the nature of the stone in this area, suggesting it is held together by a fine grout — only a master mason could have constructed a wall that so closely mimics naturally carved stone. It can destroyed using stonemason tools found in room, or by taking 10 damage (AC 10, immune to piercing and slashing damage).
The pile of debris contains nothing of significance other than discarded tools and the occasional broken weapon and humanoid bone.
Once the hidden passage has been revealed, the destruction of the stone triggers the reanimation of Talqal. Read or paraphrase the following:
As you break through the thick stone to reveal a narrow passage beyond, you hear the grind of stone on stone from behind you — the lid of the third sarcophagi falls to the floor.

A hand extends upwards, fingers flexing in its armored gloves as though testing that they still work before grasping the walls of its stone coffin. The creature sits up, and turns its head toward you, red pinpoints deep within its sockets hidden underneath a cowl cast about the room before catching your eyes. In a voice that sounds as ominous as its owner looks, the creature states:  "{@i 𝔊𝔯𝔞𝔱𝔦𝔞𝔰 𝔱𝔦𝔟𝔦 𝔞𝔤𝔬 𝔭𝔯𝔬 𝔢𝔵𝔠𝔦𝔱𝔞𝔫𝔡𝔦𝔰 𝔪𝔢.}"

Pondering the look of confusion on your face, the creature pauses a moment before repeating:  "{@i Apologies... I have not spoken in the common tongue for some time. So long I have slumbered, but I thank thee for awakening me. Welcome to the resting place of the Deathless Lady... I am Talqal}"
The language initially spoken by Talqal is Inmortui, language of the dead. His reanimation will cause the two deathless servants to cease their endless reanimation.

Talqal will be courteous toward the visitors, peaceful, and engaging, revealing as much as he sees fit (see the {@i Dramatis Personae} section). Talqal is uncertain how long he has slumbered. He will reveal that within this tomb, Nephetes-em-Xhakar rests, and that she was betrayed and entombed by those fearful of her power. A skilled deceiver, only a successful contested roll of Wisdom (Insight) against Talqal's Charisma (Deception) will suggest that Talqal is not being entirely truthful — though it is impossible to discern about what.

entries.name: 3. Concealed Hallway

entries: Unlike the other regions of this tomb that are covered in dust, this hallway is nearly immaculately clean, and appears to not have been disturbed at all for however long it had been hidden. Where the previous rooms appear to have been hastily constructed, the walls, floor, and ceiling of this hallway are perfectly smooth — a testament to the finest work of master stonemasons — and are brilliantly painted with script in a language you are unfamiliar with.

The incantations and prayers painted on the walls of the hallway are magical and aim to prevent living creatures from entering, with script in Inmortui. When a living creature starts or ends its turn in this area, it must succeed on a {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw or take 4 (1d8) necrotic damage. If a creature fails three successive saving throws, their Constitution ability score is permanently reduced by 1 (minimum 3). This effect is also present in the Guardian Cages (Area 4), and the small hallway leading to the Guard Room (Area 5), but is not present beyond that point.
If asked, Talqal will reveal that the ancient script is prayers to prevent the living from entering the tomb.

entries.name: 4. Guardian Cages
entries: The ancient civilization that constructed this tomb believed that canines, and in particular jackals, acted as guardians of the dead. Three cages containing dusty rags have been left open. While two are empty, one is not!

At the end of this hallway, a small chamber contains three steel-barred cages against a wall. Each contains a pile of rags. As you slowly move about, a low, menacing growl emanates from within the cage nearest to you. The rags are cast off, revealing a canine wrapped in funeral dressings that lunges toward you, fangs bared and tail lashing with excitement.

A {@b withered hound} will attack any living creatures nearby, though it will ignore undead creatures. The remaining cages are empty except for the rags that serve as bedding for the other withered hounds, which are resting in the Treasure Room (Area 11). The shelf against the wall contains leather collars, dishes, and training materials for the canines, well preserved but of no significant value.

entries.name: 5. Guard Room

entries: The hallway opens into a long room containing a sturdy wooden table upon which lie a number of cups and utensils along with a pair of blades that lie within reach of two seated, mummified bodies seated at either end. A third mummified body sits upon a bench along one wall. As you step foot into the room, you see pinpoints of red light illuminate within their eyeless sockets as their heads turn toward you.
Their hands grasp for their blades as they rise from their chairs...

The guard room contains three {@b deathless warriors} who will attack any living creature who enters this section of the tomb. Their weapons have been well preserved in the dry, still air of the sealed tomb. Against one wall also lies a barrel that may have once contained water, but is now empty.

Against the wall opposite the hallway leading to the room lies a false wall concealed within the stone that is revealed with a successful {@b {@dc 17} Intelligence (Investigation)} check that leads to a concealed armory. The southeast hall leads to the Sanctum of the Deathless and also has a false wall that requires a {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation)} check to notice. Both false walls can be destroyed using stonemason tools taken from the laborer's quarters, or by taking 10 damage (AC 10, immune to piercing and slashing damage).

entries.name: 6. Armory

entries: Behind the crumbled stone of a false wall lies a neatly organized armory containing racks of weapons stowed against the walls.

The weapons are elegantly designed, but in a style slightly unfamiliar to you - the spear tips, rather than the short, sharp blades you are familiar with are more akin to broad axe blades, perhaps designed to slash rather than pierce. The shields are made of hide stretched over a wooden frame.

The weapons within the armory are well-crafted, but unremarkable: three broad-bladed glaives, three hide-covered shields, half a dozen scimitars, and three sets of leather armor. A {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check when searching through the weapons will reveal one of the scimitars to be of a higher quality than the others; a {@b scimitar, +1}.

entries.name: 7. Sanctum of the Deathless
entries: The sanctum of the deathless is where the rituals that turn the willing living into the undead occur. At one end, three perfectly crafted statues of the gods of sacrifice (vulture-headed god), death (jackal-headed god), and time (ancient crone) watch over a magically contained sandstorm 10 feet in diameter. A living creature can enter this area, but takes 9 (2d8) necrotic damage at the start of each turn, which is siphoned into each of the statues. Once a creature is reduced to 0 hit points, each turn thereafter their Constitution ability score is reduced by 1. After 3 turns of their Constitution being drained, the creature's body becomes mummified. If the creature is a willing, its soul is preserved and it retains its personality and memories (this being the case with Talqal and Sethnal; if unwilling, the creature becomes a soulless undead being with no free will of its own, as was the case with the deathless servants, deathless warriors, and withered hounds).

Talqal will describe the function of this sandstorm and encourage adventurers to partake in the ritual should they choose, but will not reveal the difference between the creation of soulless or soul-preserved undead described above. Read or paraphrase the following:

The hallway opens into a long, wide room that clearly serves a religious purpose. At one end, a series of three beautifully crafted, 10-foot-high statues watch over what appears to be a self-contained sandstorm. The statues consist of a vulture-headed humanoid gazing into the mirage with hands folded before them as if in prayer and one with the features of a jackal staring greedily into the mirage, arms reaching forward. The face of the final statue is carved into the likeness of an ancient crone, wrinkled and with sunken eye sockets, who beckons gently as though in welcome. Their gaze appears to follow your movement as you observe them.

At the other end of the sanctum lie six mummified corpses upon brightly dyed and well-preserved cloth mats, each with arms folded over their chests as if in prayer. A stone dais at the end of the sanctum is presided over by a praying {@b Sethnal}. The dais contains numerous canopic jars, preservatives, and surgical tools used to delicately remove, preserve, and store vital organs from creatures whose bodies have been preserved. When ready, read the following:

At the other end of the room, six mummified bodies lay on crimson woven mats, well-preserved in the hot, dry air of the tomb. Their torsos have been opened, the cuts precise and surgical as though made by an experienced physician. Four statues watch over them, each holding a small orb that appears to be a smaller version of the sandstorm you see at the other end of the room. Beyond their bodies, a figure can be seen kneeling upon a dais that is overlooked by four statues - these ones cowled in cloaks, gesturing toward the dais in a seemingly benevolent manner. Several hundred stone vessels, each carved uniquely and with various inscriptions upon them are neatly organized around the dais.

As you watch, the kneeling figure slowly stands, its back arched as though it had been kneeling for quite some time. In a voice that reminds you of sand whistling across a barren wasteland, the figure slowly turns and addresses you:  "{@i It has been a long time since I have welcomed living guests unto this sanctum...welcome to the tomb of the Deathless Lady, whom the gods have seen fit to bless with everlasting life!}"

Sethnal and Talqal will greet each other fondly, as though it has been many centuries. A successful {@b {@dc 19} Wisdom (Insight)} check will suggest they are perhaps more familiar with one another than it might seem, but regardless their interaction seems genuine. Talqal will introduce the adventurers to Sethnal.

If either Talqal or Sethnal is harmed, or the canopic jars are damaged, the six corpses (four {@b deathless servants} and two {@b deathless warriors}) will rise and attack any living creature within the sanctum.

entries.name: 8. Hidden Hallway
entries: The concealed masonwork between the Guard Room (Area 5) and the Hidden Hallway (Area 8) is a false wall with a collapsing ceiling. It may be identified with a {@b {@dc 14} Intelligence (Investigation)} check and destroyed, requiring 10 damage (AC 10, immune to piercing and slashing damage). However, this wall has been intentionally poorly constructed — if the wall takes in excess of 15 damage, the ceiling above collapses. Any creature within 10 feet of the false wall must make a {@b {@dc 15} Dexterity} saving throw. A creature takes 16 (3d10) bludgeoning damage and is knocked prone on a failed save, or takes half as much damage and is not knocked prone on a successful one, as the ceiling collapses and rubble fills the area.

Once this false wall has been opened, the incantations and prayers aimed at preventing living creatures in the Concealed Hallway (Area 3) & Guardian Cages (Area 4) fall silent and are no longer active. Any debris caused by the collapsing false ceiling takes 1 hour per 5 feet to clear.
Once each adventurer enters this hallway, read or paraphrase the following:

As the last of you step into this 7-foot-wide hallway, a shimmering wall descends upon the entrance you just created. Touching it causes the same cold, energy-draining sensation you felt previously — though your undead hosts appear to not even notice its existence.
The hall before you is dry, clean, and unremarkable — the stone walls are completely smooth and undecorated. An eerie silence greets you.
Once the adventurers are roughly halfway down the hallway, read the following:

Warily proceeding down the hall before you, a sense of anger begins to awaken within you. As you continue onward, this rage grows, even though it seems out of place. Glancing to either side and at your companions, you notice the perfectly smooth walls of the tomb have begun to shift. At first the movement is subtle, but rapidly the masonry of the tomb walls seeps down to the floor and begins to coalesce, quickly growing in size.
The creature before you manifests into a vaguely humanoid shape, but ever shifting as though the grout of the masonry was alive.
A voice pounds in your head:  "{@i the living are forbidden from entering!}", though it makes no aggressive movement toward you.
The creature is an {@b ill-tempered grout}, and will awaken and coalesce between party members in an effort to separate them.

Upon coalescing, brightly colored murals and paintings will once again be visible upon the walls. These depict what appear to be a time of plenty, with fields of grain on either bank of a great river. Massive stone structures are also painted, some with gold paint overlaid.
Close examination of these murals will also reveal a feminine figure atop the largest of the depicted structures (what appears to be a great temple), arms outstretched to the sun above.
Once the adventurers either defeat the ill-tempered grout or entice it to join them, read the following:
The hallway turns 90 degrees to and narrows to what appears to be a dead end.
The dead end is another false wall, and can be destroyed as previously described.

entries.name: Ill-tempered Grout
entries: The ill-tempered grout is the result of centuries of exposure of the very stone of which the Deathless Lady's tomb has been constructed to the arcane incantations within that both prevent the living from entering, as well as ensuring that the body of any undead being within is reconstructed if destroyed. The ill-tempered grout has been waiting in silence for centuries, leaching nutrients from the scarce molds and lichens that exist within this tomb.

Due to its prolonged exposure to the arcane energies present within this floor, the ill-tempered grout has acquired a significant amount of knowledge, however lacks the intelligence to articulate it in a coherent manner — interacting with it can be difficult to say the least, and it appears quite unintelligent. However, it is a quick observer, perhaps due to the energies that have created it.

Frustrated at its millennia-long imprisonment, it communicates telepathically with any living being it encounters (it is unable to sense the presence of the undead). Its communication ability is limited, yet through its telepathic ability, it can discern the intent of any living creature.

The ill-tempered grout will oppose any movement by any living creature, and only allow them to pass if they agree to free it from The Living Tower. Should a living creature attempt to pass without the consent of the ill-tempered grout, it will lash out in rage.

If the ill-tempered grout accompanies the party, it will be excessively argumentative as it flows through the stone of the tower, and will always behave in a contrarian manner — even taking both sides of an argument between individuals. It will make every effort to disrupt party unity, and may insult and argue any who engage with it.

entries.name: 9. Guard Room
entries: Upon breaking the false wall, the adventurers will enter another guard room:

Once the dust settles from breaking through yet another false wall, you see a large, round table with two mummified humanoids seated as though enjoying a final meal. The table has clay dinnerware upon it, but all that remains of whatever was once there is dust. As you enter the room, the now familiar pinpricks of light burst into existence within the eye sockets of the undead. They rise, knocking their chairs over, and draw their weapons as they approach.
The two corpses are {@b deathless warriors} who will attack the adventurers. There is nothing else of note within this room.

entries.name: 10. False Inner Sanctum
entries: The false inner sanctum is a solemn place, but a decoy designed to fool any who make it this deep inside the tomb into thinking it is the final resting place of Nephetes-em-Xhakar. Once the last living creature enters this room, as with other areas, the magical barrier preventing the living from passing blocks the exit back to the previous room.

Even though you thought it impossible, this room is even more silent than other areas of the tomb; completely devoid of any sound. A feeling of reverence descends upon you, and even your undead companions appear in awe when entering this room.

Four sarcophagi rest against the opposite wall, each uniquely carved. Three familiar statues — those of the vulture, jackal, and crone — have their heads bowed as if in prayer, facing a raised stone dais upon which a fifth stone sarcophagus, this one even more ornate, rests. Stone columns, each carved in the likeness of different animals - crocodiles, vultures, jackals, horses, serpents, fish, cats, and the like - decorate the room.

The false sanctum is affected by a zone of reverence. Within this room, no sound can be made by a living creature (undead are unaffected). Attempting to speak (conversation, battle cries, or casting a spell with a verbal component, for example) results in a psychic backlash against the living creature, who must make a {@b {@dc 14} Intelligence} saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5 (1d10) psychic damage and is stunned until the start of its next turn, or takes half damage and is not stunned on a successful one. If a spell was cast, it has no effect and its spell slot is expended.

Closer examination of each of the four sarcophagi against the wall reveal that they depict the life stories of loyal servants to the Deathless Lady — they tell of humble upbringings, the learning of religious ceremonies, and a life of service dedicated to the poor, sick, and oppressed. These contain four {@b deathless priests} who will cast aside the lids to their stone sarcophagi if the large, false resting place of the Deathless Lady is disturbed.

The large sarcophagus on the raised stone dais has similar carvings, but appears to tell of a rise to greatness, a rise to power and glory where the gods themselves appear to whisper to the one whose life story is depicted. The pictographs also reveal a conquest of death, and the poor, sick, and oppressed kneeling in worship before a high priestess. This sarcophagus contains only dust. If opened, the dust explodes outward violently — each creature within 20 feet of it must make a successful {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw or be blinded for 1 turn. Opening this sarcophagus also animates the four {@b deathless priests} in the other sarcophagi. When the dust settles, there is but a single item in this tomb, in a corner of the sarcophagus and half buried in a pile of dust: a {@item lich queen's die|gp_karthax}.

The deathless priests will relentlessly attack the intruders until either side is defeated. The false wall leading to the treasure chamber can be seen with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (investigation)} check and opened as described previously.

entries.name: 11. Treasure Chamber
entries: The treasure chamber is guarded by the remaining two {@b withered hounds} who will immediately attack any intruders. When the players enter, read the following:

The narrow hallway opens into a small treasure room. This oval chamber contains two tables with untouched goblets filled with a clear liquid, with chests on either side. Laying in the center of the room, two mummified canines, raise their heads to greet you, baring their fangs with a menacing snarl.

Two tables in the room have goblets sitting on top of them; two crystal goblets on the northern table and two gold goblets on the southern. Each goblet is worth 250 gp and filled with water. The crystal goblet furthest from the western entrance is a {@item Chalice of Unholy Blessing|gp_karthax} and glows with a faint aura, noticed with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Arcana)} check. The nature of the curse will not be revealed unless a being drinks from it (see item's description).

The chests are locked, each requiring a {@b {@dc 17} Dexterity (Thieves' Tools)} check to open. The southwestern chest is trapped with a {@b thieves' counterpick} lock (see note below). The chests can be broken (AC 10, 20 hit points), but doing so causes a psychic whiplash against the attacker, who takes 16 (3d10) psychic damage if the chest is broken on this floor. The chests can be moved, but each weighs 175 pounds.

Each of the two northern chests contain gold and silver ingots worth 500 gp. A southeastern chest contains precious amethyst gems worth 2500 gp, as well as three {@item blazing ruby|gp_karthax|blazing rubies}, which sit in stark contrast to the other purple gems. The final chest, warded by the thieves' counterpick, contains 5 scrolls: {@i animate dead, death ward, speak with dead, raise dead,} and {@i remove curse}, though these scrolls are destroyed by acid if the thieves' counterpick is triggered either by forcibly opening the chest or disrupting the trap.

entries.name: Thieves' Counterpick
entries: The thieves' counterpick consists of a thin glass orb containing a highly corrosive acid that is in close proximity to the lock's tumbler mechanism. Due to its small size and integration within the locking mechanism, a {@b {@dc 17} Intelligence (Investigation)} check is required to detect it. Picking the lock requires a successful {@b {@dc 15} Dexterity (Thieves' Tools)} check, made with disadvantage if the counterpick is not detected before attempting to unlock it.
If the counterpick is triggered (on a failed check), the orb shatters and rapidly fuses the thieves' tools inside the lock, destroying the locking mechanism.

entries.name: 12. Disciple's Table
entries: An additional false wall from the treasure chamber can be destroyed as previously described.

A narrow hallway opens into a room in which a large table resides, an ornate chair of ebony at its head. Eight skeletal bodies, four with funeral wrappings, sit in plain chairs around it. Your presence causes four braziers to burst into flame, brightly illuminating the room and instantly raising the already unbearable temperature to a sweltering level. Bookshelves line either wall.
As one unit, the bodies rise and turn their heads toward you, but make no movement.
After several tense moments, one of the undead speaks to you in a clear, but raspy voice:  "{@i None of the living may enter the resting place of the Deathless Lady. She must not be awoken...}"
Six of the undead advance toward you, while the two previously seated nearest the ebony throne begin to weave their hands and utter guttural words...
Four {@b deathless servants}, two {@b deathless warriors}, and two {@b deathless priests} attack all living creatures within.

The bookshelves contain countless fragile papyrus scrolls describing an accounting of ancient history that predates even the arrival of the Eld Gods. They tell of a great civilization that spread across a southern continent for centuries, though often alluding to the ever encroaching sands that engulfed once fertile farmlands. The scrolls are not in any particular order, though if one were to take long enough to read them, would indicate an obsession with death, and what follows.

A {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check discovers the {@item Inmortui Enchiridion} laying flat on one of the bookshelves, and a {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation)} check reveals that the southeastern bookshelf can be easily moved, leading to a false wall, which connects this room to the Tomb of the Deathless Lady (Area 13).

entries.name: 13. Tomb of the Deathless Lady
entries: The sarcophagus contains Nephetes-em-Xhakar, who awakens after all adventurers have entered her tomb. The two remaining sarcophagi contain {@b deathless servants} who awaken at the same time and attack the Deathless Lady as she awakens in an effort to subdue her. Top set up this encounter, read the following:

A single brazier containing embers casts its muted flickers of light across this room from between two unadorned sarcophagi. Two statues, those of the jackal-headed god and of the crone, hold lanterns that cast an eerie, pale green glow over an ornately inscribed sarcophagus. They appear to be gazing down benevolently, as would a teacher gaze fondly upon a favored student.

Again you hear the familiar sound of stone grinding on stone as the lid to the sarcophagi near the statues becomes ajar and falls to the ground. Rising up from it, an ancient being, ornate crown upon her regal brow, settles within the eerie glow cast by the statues and smiles, turning her head toward it as though basking in the sun.
At this moment, the lids of the two sarcophagi at the back of this room open. Skeletons rise up from their tomb and, to your confusion, push past you to strike at the ancient being.
The ancient being calmly says:  "{@i Let me deal with these sentries, then we will discuss why you are here...}"

Nephetes will use her Paralyzing Touch attack on the deathless servants. Upon dispatching her attackers, if Nephetes-em-Xhakar has not been directly targeted by the adventurers, read or paraphrase the following:

After a moment she addresses you in a dry, brittle voice:  "{@i The living...long have I rested within this tomb, trapped by those who could not see the joy and love I brought to the masses from the gods. They feared what they could not understand...I have slept so long, no longer can I remember...but there was a voice, a strange being...then sleep no more.}
Talqal and Sethnal, if present, will pay homage to Nephetes, though a successful {@b {@dc 19} Wisdom (Insight)} check will indicate they are quite nervous.

If the characters engage in conversation with the Deathless Lady, she will offer immortality to any who would want it, and oversee a ritual in the Sanctum of the Deathless (Area 7) to turn any willing creature into an undead version of themselves (see page 63 for the Undead Transformation traits). She will reveal any information per the description in the {@i Dramatis Personae} as well.
If the adventurers choose to attack the Deathless Lady, read or paraphrase the following:

The ancient being before you screeches in fury as she turns to you:  "{@i I was imprisoned once by those who feared my power - now you too shall feel my wrath, for I would be free of this place at long last, parley with a god be damned!}"

Should combat against the Deathless Lady progresses well, Talqal and Sethnal will attack her as well in an effort to prevent her from being freed. Alternatively, they will attack the adventurers in a bid to demonstrate their fealty to their master if Nephetes-em-Xhakar appears to have the upper hand.

entries.name: Completing this Floor
entries: This floor may be completed in one of two ways: either the adventurers converse with the Deathless Lady, who after a time beseeches Karthax to release both the living as well as herself, or the adventurers defeat Nephetes-em-Xhakar.
If the adventurers converse with Nephetes-em-Xhakar and an Undeath ritual is completed, read the following:

The ancient crone straightens to her full height, and calls out directly to the stone:  "{@i Karthax, lord of this tower! Our deal is not yet complete, but I will retire to my tomb. I would beseech you to release these guests who have awoken me. You can find me other adventurers seeking immortality; these beings have no cause to be here any longer.}"
With a hum of magical energy and a last benevolent smile from the ancient being, arcane runes swirl about you, their intensity growing as your consciousness quickly begins to abandon you.

Your last glimpse is that of the benevolent smile turning sinister and full of malice, and your last fleeting thought is a curious question...have you just awoken a scourge than might soon be unleashed upon an unsuspecting world?
Alternatively, if the adventurers fight and defeat Nephetes-em-Xhakar, read the following:
The ancient crone crumbles before you, the ornate crown settling upon a pile of dust. The lights of the statues fade until only the crackle of the brazier is left.
With a hum of magical energy, arcane runes swirl about you, their intensity growing as your consciousness quickly abandons you.
There is always a cost for obsession. The Deathless Lady was naive and paid the price for her discovery — fear of an unknown future is a powerful motivator. 〄

entries.name: Undead Transformation
entries: If a character chooses to undergo the ritual of Nephetes-em-Xhakar and become one of the undead, the following occurs:

items: The character no longer requires air, food, drink or sleep, and does not age.
The character becomes immune to poison damage, resistant to necrotic damage, but vulnerable to radiant damage.
The character becomes immune to the following conditions: charmed, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, stunned.
The character's Constitution ability score increases by 2, but its Charisma ability score is reduced by 2.
The character's creature type is replaced with Undead.

{@b New Trait: Undead Fortitude}. If damage reduces the character to 0 hit points, it must make a saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the character drops to 1 hit point instead.
{@b New Trait: Turn Defiance}. The character has advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

entries: Otherwise, the character retains its personality, knowledge, and abilities that it knew in life.

entries.name: Background.
entries: Even the so-called Eld Gods, as they were known, were not without their own enemies. Despite their immense magical powers and seemingly immortal lifespan, they were not the sole beings of power from other places. Other extraplanar beings, often with origins the Eld Gods had not explored or simply could not fathom, were also capable of exploring new worlds. Some of these were powerful, monstrous beings that were spawned from a place only known as the Abyss.

Encounters with creatures from the Abyss were infrequent due to the apparent fact that these vile creatures had apparently only recently discovered this world due to sheer happenstance. Thus the gaze of these beings, known to the Eld Gods and mortals alike as "demonkind", had not turned to this yet uncorrupted world.
The Eld Gods greatly preferred it that way.

In the age prior to the Great Cataclysm, the Eld Gods, sensed demonkind could yet be a grave danger to themselves, the mortals they ruled over, and all they had constructed on this world. Several of the Eld Gods thus spent centuries hunting down and exterminating demonkind; wiping the last traces of them from the world. That is, all but a handful — for one of the Eld Gods, who above all else desired power, saw that demonkind could potentially be of use to them. Weaving a mighty spell, the Eld God ensnared the last vestiges of demonkind into a self-contained dimension only they could access. The remaining gods, convinced demonkind had been eradicated, resumed the Great Debate.

The greatest of these remaining demons, the one known as Raz'Drexin, raged and consumed others of their ilk while imprisoned, all the while nurturing a burning desire for vengeance against those who would prevent demonkind's ascension over this world.

After several centuries of imprisonment, solitude, and growing insanity, Raz'Drexin was abruptly freed — the one who had imprisoned them unleashed the demon into the world in an act of desperation during the Great Cataclysm. As fire rained down upon the world and rivers of mortal blood poured forth, as the earth was sundered and floods consumed what little remained, Raz'Drexin, insane, bloodthirsty, and burning for revenge, sought out the Eld God who had imprisoned them. At the height of the Great Cataclysm, launched an assault against the one who would seek to harness the powers of demonkind for their own. Ironically, it was the assault conducted by a maddened demon of darkness and chaos on the Eld Gods that ultimately allowed the Gods of Order to prevail, settling the great debate.

With vengeance at last theirs, Raz'Drexin contented themselves to wait in the darkness for the time demons would once again discover this world. Raz'Drexin preyed upon mortals from the shadows, consuming nightmares and growing more powerful. That is until within The Living Tower Karthax struck a bargain with the demon, luring them within. Initially, only Karthax and Raz'Drexin know what terms were agreed...

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: We envisioned this floor as one of complete and utter horror. What chaos and evil would a powerful demon unleash upon beings who would not bend to their will? What sorts of monstrous deeds would the demon perform out of frustration at being tricked into being restrained by the power of an Eld God? Perhaps most importantly, what would that demon do to attempt to escape and spread their evil influence into an unsuspecting world?

As this floor is written, Raz'Drexin has been tricked and contained by Karthax, and only by crafting a seemingly innocent item - a band of copper upon a desk - could the demon hope to trick an unsuspecting being into lowering the magical incantations containing their essence. While imprisoned within a small chamber, the only way Raz'Drexin could hope to be freed is by infiltrating the mind of visitors to this floor - those willing to serve would aid the demon in hopefully eliminating the spells binding the demon herein. If unsuccessful, at least they could serve as useful vassals to the outside world, able to spread demonic influences and thus set in motion the seeds for a later demonic invasion.

Those who would not willingly aid such a being of pure evil would no doubt be met with a gruesome fate for the amusement of Raz'Drexin by taking over their minds. Even a loyal friend could be turned against a boon companion - and what worse horror could there be than having one's consciousness be awake and aware, witnessing their own hands perform unspeakable acts?
Consider the following while having adventurers explore this floor:

items: How would ebon spirits and echoes of demonkind - the last vestiges of those demons once trapped alongside the more powerful Raz'Drexin behave once unleashed from the Chambers of Sacrifice, Pain, Darkness, and Mystery?

Garion, once a bard of some renown, is one whose mind has been weakened - even decimated - by Raz'Drexin's relentless assaults upon his psyche. As such, Raz'Drexin is able to fully control Garion's actions. While most characters of good alignment might react with compassion, Raz'Drexin will seek to take advantage and manipulate their good intentions for their own amusement.

Similarly, evil-aligned characters might have a different reaction. Being motivated to both escape or at least spread the influence of demonkind through willing servants to the outside world, consider the character's motivations in how to best convince them to join with Raz'Drexin.

Raz'Drexin is meant to be roleplayed as evil, cunning, sinister, remorseless, and completely insane. Their only motivation is to escape and prepare the world for a demonic invasion - if a character (or characters) willingly succumb to the demon's influence and truly allow them to escape, this might set the tone for a later demon invasion in your campaign.

entries.name: Raz'Drexin, Bane of the Eld Gods
entries: Raz'Drexin is the last of demonkind in this world — at least to their knowledge. After the Eld Gods relentlessly and ruthlessly hunted down and exterminated all but a few of these powerful beings, one of the Gods saw they could potentially bend demonkind to their will. As Raz'Drexin and their servants made their last stand against this God, a powerful spell of containment was cast, trapping Raz'Drexin and their ilk in a small, extradimensional space that was hidden from all scrying.

This Eld God deceived their fellow deities, tricking them into believing that demonkind had been eradicated permanently, the taint of demonic influence scoured clean from the world. For a time all was well, and the Eld God patiently used their time to secretly search for the origins of demonkind. During this time, the Eld God searched for any artifacts that might provide clues as to how to summon and control demons from other planes of existence.

While imprisoned in their extradimensional space, the demons raged at first at their incarceration, cast their spells in an attempt to escape, and eventually in their frustration turned on each other. As the most powerful, Raz'Drexin consumed the demonic essences of their companions, absorbing both their powers and their personalities — an act, along with further centuries of solitude, that would drive the demon insane.

While the Great Cataclysm was underway and convinced in their own ability to control demonkind, the Eld God who initially imprisoned the remaining demons chose to open the extradimensional space and bind the demons to their will, not knowing that Raz'Drexin had absorbed their essences and grown exponentially more powerful. While demons of lesser power might have been ensnared in the Eld Gods spells, the multitude of minds now inhabiting the demon's shadowy form allowed them to evade the enchantments that otherwise would have rendered even a powerful demon a willing servant to the deity. Thus Raz'Drexin was unleashed once again upon the world to prey upon the hopes and dreams of its inhabitants.

The escape of Raz'Drexin remained secret, despite clues to the continued existence of demonkind. Entire villages far away from the front lines were massacred by an unknown, malevolent force. Rumors of shadowy figures assaulting settlements became frequent, as did tales of individuals of otherwise sound mind waking one day suddenly either insane and prone to violent outbursts and speaking in unknown tongues or others merely becoming catatonic.

At the height of the Great Cataclysm, the Eld Gods were consumed with their conflict as Raz'Drexin's influence began to grow. At long last, the demon saw the opening they had been waiting for — the Eld God responsible for the demon's imprisonment had become distracted and arrogant — and sent forth their elite guard to seemingly secure a glorious victory for themselves.

Sensing vengeance at last was theirs, Raz'Drexin unleashed themselves upon the Eld God. The demon was preparing for the final blow but was driven off by the returning guard, disappearing once more into the shadows. Shorn of leadership and with their morale dealt a devastating blow, what surely would have been a glorious victory was turned into a resounding defeat, the forces of Order overcoming what had seemed insurmountable odds to drive their opponents away. It was this battle at the height of the Great Cataclysm that ultimately turned the tide toward Order.

Despite not completely eliminating their former captor, Raz'Drexin continued with their nefarious deeds even when the Great Debate was at last settled. The outcome of the Great Cataclysm was more than the demon could hope for — their captor weakened, humiliated, and banished, a world torn asunder by fire and thus perfect to spread the influence of demonkind once again.

For countless centuries after, Raz'Drexin lurked in the shadows, seeking ways to prepare for the inevitable rediscovery of this world by demonkind. Raz'Drexin constructed powerful artifacts with which to ensure that even if the demon was captured or destroyed, their essence would linger. Seemingly innocuous and mundane items were imbued with Raz'Drexin's power, that when used would infect the minds of those who possessed them. Enchanted mirrors, candles, and other objects used by seers and scryers allowed Raz'Drexin to slip into the minds of powerful mortals possessing magical gifts. In exchange for promises of untold power, these mortals would begin amassing a following that were the seeds of a mortal army loyal to demonkind — and Raz'Drexin, in particular.

Despite their continued search for ways to prepare for a demonic invasion, Raz'Drexin remained unable to communicate with their extraplanar brethren. The demon searched the world for centuries, until they came across a crumbling tower. Sensing the lingering and hated presence of one of the Eld Gods, Raz'Drexin entered the tower. Karthax, recognizing the shadow demon as a key reason behind the triumph of Order, nonetheless held true to their vision of free will and offered the demon a bargain: the means to contact demonkind outside this world in exchange for their service within The Living Tower.

Having searched desperately for a means to do just that, Raz'Drexin eagerly agreed before negotiating the terms of what defined service within The Living Tower. The demon was thus deceived, their spirit trapped once more by one of the Eld Gods within a floor of obsidian walls.

While outwardly raging at their imprisonment once more, secretly the demon knew that at last they held the upper hand — for the seemingly mundane items imbued with their essence throughout the world would ensure that their influence would spread, and eventually the demon would be free once again — this time with a legion of followers. Karthax the Deceiver had perhaps, for once, been themselves deceived.
Only a fool would chance the release of the last of demonkind.  〄

While imprisoned within The Living Tower, Raz'Drexin is only able to communicate telepathically and send forth lesser versions of themself — demonic echoes consisting of flame, fire, and blood. Having consumed the minds of numerous beings, demon and mortal alike, the demon's telepathic voice consists of countless voices all desperately attempting to speak over each other and be heard. Only the very wise or intelligent can hope to discern the true voice of Raz'Drexin, and those of insufficient ability suffer terrible headaches from the relentless pressure applied to their minds.

Raz'Drexin is malicious, cunning, and revels in driving mortal minds insane, turning fast friends and lovers against each other. While the influence of the demon is near, rest is impossible, as the demon's mind relentlessly seeks to penetrate into the hopes and dreams of mortals and thereby bend them to their will. Should a creature eventually collapse and sleep out of sheer exhaustion, Raz'Drexin will enter their minds and consume their dreams and essence — causing any number of afflictions of the mind among those who have been touched by the demon.

{@b Roleplaying Raz'Drexin.} Raz'Drexin's personality is ever shifting, much like a shadow cast by a candle flame dancing on the wall — one moment nearly seductive, the next unleashing foul curses at those upon his floor. They are also pure and utter evil and itching to spread their influence upon the world of mortals. The demon is also intensely angered at being tricked by Karthax, but knows that soon enough their time will come. Raz'Drexin will communicate telepathically with adventurers, and also possess Garion, the last remaining survivor of a group on this floor whose mind has nearly been completely overwhelmed by the demon. Above all, the demon will use every tool to terrify visitors into submission and subservience to them. Those the demon cannot sway face a potential gruesome fate. Raz'Drexin can be voiced as follows:

items: When interacting with newcomers, in a shrieking telepathic voice:  "{@i The Deceiver sends yet more playthings to my domain...so glad, my boredom is never pleasant for my guests...}"

When attempted to entice a character into service as an acolyte, in a telepathic tone as smooth as the finest silk:  "{@i Come now, I could offer you more than your feeble imagination could conceive...power, praise, and wealth could all be yours if you but lend me an ear...and perhaps an arm...}"

If enticed into describing how they came into this floor, in a tone dripping in hatred but also barely concealed excitement:  "{@i The Deceiver, the one others call Karthax...he deceived them all long ago, each of the damned Eld Gods, the name those pathetic mortals used to call them. Eventually, I sensed their presence once again, and I entered here so that I might once again contact my brethren.}"

If asked about demonkind, in a telepathic rage (each creature on the floor taking 6 (1d12) psychic damage, no saving throw):  "{@i I AM THE LAST! THOSE DAMNED FOUL CREATURES CALLED ME EVIL, BUT THEY EXTERMINATED ALL OF US! Or nearly all...I consumed the last of those pathetic excuses who could not bear imprisonment any longer. Now, they serve me...}"
If possessing Garion's body:  "{@i Filthy bags of putrid flesh...I can feel myself rot in this pathetic excuse for a vessel.}"

entries.name: Garion, Surrogate of Raz'Drexin
entries: Garion was once a handsome human bard of some renown. Muscular, charming, with a finely sculpted beard, and piercing blue eyes, Garion sang and strummed a lute like few others, and many buildings were crammed with visitors hoping to catch a tune or three. From city to village, tavern to inn, Garion was perpetually restless and never tarried in one place for more than a fortnight.

An accomplished gambler, Garion lost his coin as quickly as he could earn it more often than not. At times, the smooth-tongued bard would be able to worm his way out of delicate situations; at other times his approach met with less than desirable results from his perspective. It was one of these latter situations that found the bard needing to lay low for a while. Having heard of a booming new industry where perhaps his former business associates might not think to look (until things cooled off a bit),  Garion ventured north to the various mining settlements that sprung up seemingly overnight — rowdy taverns full of newly wealthy people sounded quite appealing.

For a week or so, all was well until Garion's penchant for crossing the wrong individuals came to the fore over a rigged set of gaming dice, and, in the dead of night, the bard left for the next settlement. However, the bard was not so adept at navigating directions in the black of night and thus became hopelessly lost. Eventually, parched and in tattered rags, Garion found himself at the entrance to an abandoned tower.

Karthax, disgusted by the pathetic whining mortal that somehow survived the wastelands long enough to venture into The Living Tower, offered to settle Garion's debts if he would spend a fortnight with a shadow. If the bard survived the utter black evil that was but an echo of Raz'Drexin's true self, the human would no doubt never whine again.

Raz'Drexin, seeing a weak minded fool but one with a great deal of fame, set to the task of breaking the spirit and mind of Garion. Once broken completely, Raz'Drexin surmised, the foolish mortal could be a useful vassal for spreading his influence. Since this time, several visitors have come to this floor, and a possessed Garion has assaulted their minds by the will of Raz'Drexin; directing them to perform unspeakable acts against one another...until the screams cease. Afterwards, what remains is the telepathic presence of the demon, endlessly pressing against Garion's mind and taunting him with the heinous acts he's performed while controlled.

Garion's body has also slowly been warped by Raz'Drexin's evil influence: Cloven hooves have replaced once muscular legs, a long, sinuous tail erupts from his lower back, a series of horns have sprouted from the human's skull, and his skin has begun to turn the color of twilight. However, what is  most disconcerting, is that Garion's once piercing, laughing blue eyes have been replaced with a dull,  milky glaze — that turns to jet once the demon  possesses his mind.

{@b Roleplaying Garion.} Garion has been driven nearly completely insane by the horrors he has witnessed due to Raz'Drexin overwhelming the minds and spirits of visitors to this floor. He will say little, other than incoherent babblings — though at times, Garion will also, in a disturbingly lucid voice, state:

items: If the adventurers proceed to a new room, in a shriek:  "{@i NOOOOO!! The master will not like it if you go in there!!!" or "Don't...go...there...bad things happened to the elf...}"
If a soothing song is played, Garion might calm his babblings long enough to fall nearly asleep, before jolting awake again and shrieking in terror.
If about to be possessed by Raz'Drexin:  "{@i I feel the master's presence...no, No, NO, master, please not again, I beg of you! AAAIIEEEEE!}"

entries.name: Arioch Morningstar
entries: A male elf with long, black hair and clad in supple gray and maroon leathers, Arioch Morningstar was once a young, brash elf who, rather than take up a peaceful life of quiet contemplation that most elves would prefer, set out to seek adventure.

Adventuring was not what the bards and minstrels described in the great ballads and sagas of elvenkind, as Arioch quickly found out. Rather than be rewarded for good deeds, Arioch quickly discovered that good deeds often go unnoticed, and there is much injustice in the world that cannot easily be overcome.

Seeking simply to make a living rather than change the world, the elf quickly became angry and bitter at the injustices he saw. He turned to a mercenary life, where at least his deeds might be rewarded with a bit of coin at the end of the contract. Arioch took up the blade and stave.

While on his travels, Arioch began to see at last what he missed all along — that yes, there is great wrong, and it is easy to see crime, abuse, discrimination, and inequality, but more difficult to see were the smaller, seemingly minor deeds in his youth that were easily discounted but made all the difference: the gentle acts of kindness, of sharing a humble meal with a stranger, and of welcoming a bitter elven mercenary into one's home on a bitterly cold night.

Seeing the balance of right and wrong, ill deed and good, Arioch forged a different, perhaps gentler path. Rather than seething at injustice, Arioch instead began to try to understand the choices that led to ill deeds, as well as see their potential good outcome. Vice versa, a noble and altruistic deed might lead to a horrible act. Balance, the elf came to realize, is the only truth. He came to neither favor good nor evil, but instead acknowledge that both must be kept in balance — and if violence is required to keep either in check, so be it.

Sensing an unbalance in nature, perhaps caused by yet another greedy scheme in which the wealthy merely exploit the land for their own gain, Arioch ventured to where he sensed the disturbance. Frontier mining camps and settlements not being the source, Arioch ventured into a barren wasteland, and before long came to The Living Tower. Sensing the tower itself as the disturbance that had slowly been growing in strength, the elf willingly entered without hesitation — much to the surprise of Karthax.

{@b Roleplaying Arioch Morningstar.} Once a skilled mercenary and warrior, Arioch Morningstar has been on a long path seeking balance both within himself and for the world. In his youth, most who encountered the elf would have described him as aggressive, impulsive, and even reckless. However, with age comes wisdom. Now Arioch is best described as thoughtful, measured, and observant; one who thinks before he acts and looks for solutions before violence — even though he is more than capable with an axe, sword, or stave. Arioch can be portrayed as follows:

items: When describing how he came to The Living Tower:  "{@i I sensed a disturbance in the balance...I now know it is within this tower. But this...this place is pure evil. It must be destroyed.}"
When interacting with the Raz'Drexin or the possessed Garion, Arioch will attempt to drive its presence away and refuse any overtures made to him by the demon.

Arioch will be thoughtful and observant, studying each aspect of the floor with the grim feature of an elf who has seen similar things before. He will also touch little unless necessary, and attempt to destroy any items of malevolent intent.

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Glyph

entries: The magic that enveloped your senses begins to dissipate, and despite the nausea that once threatened to overwhelm your senses you are actually able to retain both your balance and consciousness, though you drop to your knees as soon as the magic releases you. With a sense of something vaguely akin to relief you rise from your knees and take stock of your surroundings. Almost immediately that sense of relief turns to a sense of horror, and the nausea returns with vengeance. Not because of the Karthax's magic, but because of the horrors that greet you.

Corpses...dismembered in a hideous, gruesome scene only found in your darkest nightmares. Many of them have been positioned intentionally in grotesque postures made possible only by the shattering of their limbs as their faces gaze to the ceiling, mouths open as though screaming in unending agony. The sight of so many corpses that have clearly been tortured and defiled before their final breath turns your blood to ice in your veins.

Worse is the stench of this...charnel house of horror. The stench of rotten blood overwhelms your senses and a wave of nausea - more potent than any of The Living Tower's magic - causes the bile to quickly rise in your throat.
Immediately have the adventurers make a {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw or have them vomit and retch, and if they fail their save by 5 or more, they take one level of exhaustion.
After allowing the adventurers to take in their surroundings, read or paraphrase the following:

The pentagonal room you find yourself in has been carved from the blackest of obsidian, with only the irregular spatter of seams in the volcanic stone on the floor, walls, and ceiling hinting that the room was constructed. At the midpoint of each of the five walls of the room, braziers blazing with an eerie, pale blue flame have been lit, and between each is a crackling barrier of what appears to be flame unlike no other you have seen. The flames writhe in shapes that dance as though alive, in shapes that at times you swear seem to be calling out silently in screams as though countless souls were desperate to escape.
Taking in the horror of this room you hear a pitiful whimper, followed by a soft murmur in a corner.

Approaching, you see a shivering figure being wrapped in the cloak of a kneeling humanoid attempting to comfort them. The second figure rises, and without turning to speak, addresses you:  "{@i So...more have made it to this... this... slaughterhouse. Pray for a quick death, for otherwise it seems we will suffer endlessly.}

The second figure is {@b Arioch Morningstar}, who will reveal all that he knows willingly and aid the adventurers however possible. The shivering figure is {@b Garion}, sole survivor of this floor and surrogate of Raz'Drexin. Read or paraphrase the following once they approach:

The shivering figure, wrapped in Arioch's cloak, has their back turned to you. As they attempt to cower further into the corner away from you, the cloth falls from their head and shoulders...to your shock, a series of horns are visible from the...creature's...head, and their skin is tinged as though the writhing shadows beyond the braziers have begun to infect the man before you. A long, sinuous tail twitches from beneath the cloak, uncontrollably at first.

After a few moments, the tail falls still and the whimpering ceases. The beings face turns toward you, a cruel smile slashed across their face. Pure black eyes greet you, and cruel, mocking words issue forth:  "{@i So, Karthax has sent me more playthings...more mortals for my amusement...let us begin our little game. The rules are quite simple - release me and swear allegiance to me forevermore. Refuse, or be of insufficient strength....and this shall be your fate - my menagerie of the damned!}"

With that, the jet black eyes immediately become milky and glazed over, and with a soft cry of pain, the pitiful wretch before you resumes his cowering, speaking to himself in a tongue you cannot understand.
After allowing this to sink in, continue with the following:
The braziers at the top of the room flash with a nearly blinding pale blue light before they fall silent. The path has been cleared...

entries.name: Demonflame Barrier
entries: The flames between the lit braziers are made of demonflame, and contain the souls of those tortured and slain creatures who found their way to this floor.

Any living creature that touches the flames takes 9 (2d8) fire plus 9 (2d8) necrotic damage (no saving throw). The demonflame barrier may be lowered by Raz'Drexin, but is otherwise impenetrable and can't be dispelled by any magic short of a {@i wish} spell.

entries.name: 2. Chamber of Sacrifice

entries: Before you stands a tall statue of a hooded and cloaked figure bearing a vessel, its face completely smooth beneath its cowl. A faint blood-hued light emanates softly from the vessel, beckoning you closer.
An altar lays at the figure's feet; a single jagged obsidian knife upon it. The altar is caked in dried blood. The stench of iron is heavy on your nose.

The vessel held by the statue, upon closer inspection, is inlaid with bloodstones and runes carved in Abyssal that speak to an incantation of sacrifice that must be offered. A creature must use the obsidian knife to offer its own blood, sacrificing 2d6 hit points to fill the vessel with a sufficient amount of blood to lower the demonflame barrier to the Chamber of Pain. Once the vessel is filled with sufficient blood, it is magically siphoned away, and an {@b ebon spirit} coalesces in the central room — this ebon spirit may or may not immediately engage with the adventurers per the GM's discretion.

Per the GM's discretion, Raz'Drexin may choose to telepathically communicate with the adventurer (or adventurers) who used their blood in the chamber of sacrifice — taunting them, or depending on if the being is a magic user, attempt to entice them into Raz'Drexin's service.
When the adventurers re-enter the central chamber, read the following:
The pitiful, whimpering being in the corner unleashes an anguished wail at some unseen force:  "{@i Master! No! I promised...NOOOOOO!}" before violently convulsing."
After but a moment, the convulsing stops and the cruel, mocking voice addresses you once again:  "{@i Thank you, wretches, for your kind offering. But I would seek more...}"

The wretch's eyes roll back in their head, and eyes once black as the obsidian from which this floor has been constructed once again turn milky white and distant. The cruel voice is once again replaced by whimpers and incoherent babbles in what might be several tongues intermixed...but it is hard to decipher anything coherent.

If Garion's body is harmed, Raz'Drexin will unleash a powerful psychic scream - each creature in the main chamber must make a {@b {@dc 15} Charisma} saving throw, taking 11 (2d10) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. The {@b ebon spirit} will remain hidden in one of the corners, watching and observing.
None deserve to be tormented by a trapped demon of shadow. 〄

entries.name: 3. Chamber of Pain

entries: Passing through another set of now silent braziers, you witness a horror beyond that which you thought possible after seeing the grotesque mutilations in the central chamber.

The obsidian walls of this chamber have been lined with cruel spikes of numerous designs: some needle-thin and long, some thick and wickedly curved upward - several caked with dried blood. Others are thick and contain reverse-facing barbs that contain rotting entrails upon them, and some blades are dull...rusted...intentionally left so, it would seem.
The room is illuminated by an iron stove containing burning coal embers that have clearly begun to cool. Your brow immediately begins to sweat from the oppressive heat.

Despite the heat and gore within the room, the sickly smell of roasted meat also greets you....unfortunately, to your horror, the source is a dismembered corpse that has been placed upon the stove and is charred. The sizzle of fat dripping upon the coals, were it anything other than a humanoid, and in such a house of horrors, might once have been enticing.

Next to the stove, a spoked iron wheel with short spikes along its circumference is held up by a wooden scaffold, bits of dried flesh upon the spikes. Thick leather straps stained red from blood are affixed equidistant upon the wheel.

A table along the opposite wall contains all manner of instruments of horror: hammers, chisels, razor-sharp, thin knives, whips (one with razor blades attached along its length), chains, and some devices whose purpose eludes you - though based on the blood caked upon the table, you have no desire to observe their function.
Abyssal runes, crudely drawn in blood and excrement on the walls, suggest, once again, an offering is required.

To open the next chamber, a sacrifice of pain must be offered by one of four methods: a slow impalement upon one of the wall spikes, being burned by the charcoal stove, by being strapped to the breaking wheel and having another companion inflict pain upon a willing creature, or by using the instruments of torture.

Once a creature has taken 14 (4d6) damage from whatever method chosen, the next series of braziers will darken and open the path to the Chamber of Darkness. An {@b ebon spirit} will also spawn in the central chamber.

If any of the tools in the chamber are damaged, Raz'Drexin will unleash a powerful psychic scream - each creature in the main chamber taking 11 (2d10) psychic damage on a failed {@b {@dc 15} Charisma} saving throw, or half as much on a successful one. Should the creature fail their save by 5 or more, they will also suffer one level of exhaustion.

Raz'Drexin will telepathically communicate with whatever creature inflicted pain upon another, sensing an opportunity to sway their nature toward evil. With enticing and manipulative words, Raz'Drexin will attempt to sway them into their service.
If the adventurers choose to use Garion as the sacrificial victim, he will show no outward indication he is feeling pain. Instead, half way through the sacrifice of pain, read the following:

The twisted human before you, still muttering but otherwise showing no indication of feeling what you are beginning to inflict upon him, pauses his incessant babbling for a moment, milky eyes becoming black as night. With a wicked, toothy grin, they address you:  "{@i Good...now, more...}"
With those short words, the eyes roll back and once again become sightless and unfocused - the malevolent presence has left again.
Once the adventurers re-enter the central chamber, two {@b ebon spirits} await, and may engage, or will watch from the shadows.

entries.name: 4. Chamber of Darkness
entries: The pale blue, glowing braziers barring this chamber have fallen silent once the Chamber of Pain has been satiated.
Entering this room, a great sense of emptiness washes over you, and the temperature drops. All is still within the room.
The cruel voice enters your mind once more:  "{@i Few have the stomach to do what you did. Allow the blackness to take you...embrace your cruelty, and bind yourself to me!}"

If the adventurers give any indication of resisting Raz'Drexin's overture, two {@b echoes of demonkind} will attack — at the GM's discretion, the {@b ebon spirits} that have coalesced in the central chamber may also attack.
Once defeated, read the following:

The pressure on the inside of your skull grows, and the voice - now with a growing frustration compared to the honeyed, mocking tones previously used - addresses you:  "{@i Still you resist your true nature! You will not leave unless I wish it...I will be unleashed once again! Not even a god can contain my wrath!}"
As the pressure inside your skull eases, it is replaced by another sensation from outside. An almost palpable sense of...concern. Concern or trepidation, you are not sure which.
Garion will continue uninterrupted, but his chanting, rocking, keening, and whimpering will become more urgent, as though sensing the potential release of Raz'Drexin.

entries.name: 5. Chamber of Mystery
entries: Once the {@b echoes of demonkind} and {@b ebon spirits} have been defeated, the braziers leading to the Chamber of Mystery fall silent, and the path is clear.

Unlike the horrors of the other rooms you have left behind, this room is a nearly welcome site. Four obsidian statues face inward to a sturdy, well-carved ebony desk, behind which a comfortable looking chair sits. Bookshelves line the walls.
The air in this chamber is still, calm, and dusty. Had you not recently witnessed unspeakable horrors, you might mistake this room for a musty, old wizard's chamber.

The tomes upon the bookshelves contain numerous books, scrolls, manuscripts, and tomes. Closer inspection reveals their true nature: grimoires of sacrifice penned in the vile, written Abyssal script using blood. Several of the books are bound in human-skin leather and depict sacrificial rituals and incantations used to siphon the energy from a living being by means of torture methods most vile.

If an adventurer spends 30 minutes and makes a successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation)} check, they discover a grimoire in which the following spells have been scribed: {@i circle of death, contact other plane, dominate person, fear, phantasmal killer, suggestion,} and {@i vampiric touch}.
Upon inspecting the ebony table, read or paraphrase the following:
The surface of the ebony table is smooth, flawless, and completely devoid of dust. A single, unremarkable copper hoop sits on its center.

A successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Arcana)} check will indicate the hoop is magical, though the nature of the magic is unknown. A character must attune to the cooper hoop (a {@b demon's tunnel}) to use it.
The Abyssal runes for "blood", "sacrifice", "darkness", and "mystery" are carved upon the band.

Raz'Drexin created these simple bands in an effort to get potential visitors to lower the barriers containing their essence by traveling through the teleportation tunnel outside the Ring of Containment that restricts the demon's movement.

entries.name: Demon's Tunnel
entries: {@i Wondrous item, very rare (requires attunement)}

This unremarkable copper hoop is roughly the size of a large ring, and can be worn as such. Crafted by a lesser demon, this item is commonly referred to as {@i Trevor's Teleportation Tunnel}. Instructions for its use are engraved in Abyssal on the band.

While attuned, you learn how to read, speak, and write Abyssal if you don't already know how to do so. Additionally, You can toss the ring into the air while speaking one of the tunnel's command words: "blood", "sacrifice", "darkness", or "mystery". The ring will magically reshape itself, forming a frame 3-feet by 4-feet in size, and hover 2 feet off the floor, each corresponding to another area of Raz'Drexin's floor. Once a command word has been used to activate the band, a teleportation tunnel to another region of the floor will remain open for 1 hour.
{@item Demon's Tunnel|gp_karthax}

entries.name: 6. Demon's Chamber
entries: Once one of the scrolls powering the ring of containment has been disturbed, Raz'Drexin is released and will await the adventurers in the central chamber. Read or paraphrase the following:
Stepping back through the teleportation tunnel you activated, you are greeted by a figure unlike that which you have ever beheld.

A being of the blackest shadow stretches out limbs tipped with vicious claws of darkness. Before it, levitating 2 feet off the ground is the poor wretch that clearly has been terrorized by the being before you. The shadow demon softly whispers to the wretch:  "{@i Though you hardly deserve it, I shall grant you the release you have begged of me. You have been...an adequate servant.}"
With a slight gesture of a claw and a flare of demonflame from within its shadowy form, the wretch's neck snaps and their corpse falls to the ground.

A wide, evil fanged slash of a grin spreads across their face as the demon advances toward you:  "{@i You should have bound yourself to me...better to be at my side than in my way. No matter, there were others before you, and will certainly be more after. Now...die...}"
Raz'Drexin will engage and attempt to kill all adventurers on this floor, preferentially targeting any who spurned their offers and enticements into their service.

entries.name: 7. Ring of Containment
entries: Circling the inner chambers of Raz'Drexin's floor is a sphere of obsidian that contains magical incantations that keep Raz'Drexin's essence contained within the inner chambers. Characters will not be able to access this sphere.

entries.name: 8. Tunnel Exit
entries: Depending on which word ("blood", "sacrifice", "darkness", or "mystery") an adventurer uses to activate the demon's tunnel, they will open a tunnel to an offering room. Each is identical. Read or paraphrase the following:

Crouching to step through the tunnel, you are surprised to find yourself in a room no longer made of carved obsidian, but rather from the stone, you recognize the foundation The Living Tower is made from. The air is warm, even pleasant, and smells faintly of slightly damp stone - but otherwise this room is unremarkable. On the other side of the room are two sturdy, wooden doors opposite each other.

entries.name: 9. Scrolls of Containment

entries: Two stone statues - carved of the same stone from which the tower itself has been constructed - seem vaguely familiar, one with female features, the other male - but both androgynous enough to be either gender. Each gestures to a levitating scroll between them.
The scrolls vary depending on which word the adventurer used to activate the demon tunnel:

items: Sacrifice: a scroll of {@i planar binding}
Pain: a scroll of {@i forbiddance}
Darkness: a scroll of {@i dispel evil and good}
Mystery: a scroll of {@i antimagic field}

entries: Once the scroll has been touched, read the following:

The sense of trepidation that has been steadily growing since you defeated the shadow demons has now grown to alarm. The instant you touch the scroll, an urgent voice booms out:  "{@i Fool! Even good intent can lead to great evil! Your choice might yet release unspeakable horror upon the mortal races!}"

The voice falls silent, and a great, insane laughter cackles in your head:  "{@i Yes! YEEESSS! I shall be free! You who have not taken up my offer...you have but glimpsed a taste of the suffering that I shall unleash upon you!}"
The braziers to the Demon's Chamber fall silent, releasing Raz'Drexin, who has been contained within.

entries.name: Fern's Finicky Flask
entries: {@i Wondrous item, very rare}

This glass flask is wrapped in bands of copper, silver, and gold, and has a stopper of solid gold. Long ago, a powerful magus grew weary of identifying the myriad of philters, potions, poisons, and other concoctions brought to them — thus they created this flask to aid in the identification of such liquids.

When a small amount of solution is placed within the flask and swirled, the flask glass will color according to the solution's properties. Harmful potions such as poisons cause the glass to tint black, potions with a healing or regenerative effect tint the glass green, potions that grant an imbiber resistance to some effect will turn the glass white, and otherwise neutral or harmless potions tint the glass blue.
The solution itself remains its original color. The flask will revert to its transparent state after 1 hour.
{@item Fern's Finicky Flask}

entries.name: Ring of Ruby Tears
entries: {@i Wondrous item (ring), very rare (requires attunement)}

While wearing this ring, you add an additional die of damage to any melee attacks you make while your hit points are under half their maximum. Additionally, your melee attacks are considered magical even if the weapon you are bearing is not.

entries.name: 10. Treasure Chests

entries: Three simple, wood chests banded in iron are neatly arranged against the wall opposite a wooden table.

Each chest is unlocked. Two of the chests within each room are empty, containing nothing but dust — but, at the GM's discretion, may release an {@b ebon spirit} to attack the adventurers who open the chest. The third is trapped with a weakening affliction trap, and contains treasure depending on the word used to activate the demon tunnel:

items: Sacrifice: Fern's Finicky Flask
Pain: 1 potion of mind reading and 1 potion of fire giant strength
Darkness: potion of invisibility and 250 gp
Mystery: ring of ruby tears

entries.name: Weakening Affliction
entries: {@i Magical trap (necromancy)}

A creature touching an item imbued with a weakening affliction trap must succeed on a {@b {@dc 13} Constitution} saving throw or the limb that touched the trap will go numb. Any attack rolls or ability checks made using the affected limb are made with disadvantage.
This effect lasts for 24 hours, or until removed with a {@i lesser restoration} spell.
The trap may be identified with a successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Arcana)} check and dispelled with a successful DC 14 {@i dispel magic} spell.

entries.name: Completing this Floor
entries: This floor is completed when Raz'Drexin has been defeated. Once the demon has been reduced to 0 hit points, read or paraphrase the following:

The demon's shadowy figure begins to dissipate as though a mist begins to disperse in the first rays of the morning sun. As it does so, tendrils of energy lash out from the room that contained it, and slowly drag the weakening demon back into the room, despite its pleas and vile curses alike.
